Project: Search Ads Copy
What you‚Äôll do
‚óè Create Responsive Search Ads (RSAs) for your ad groups
‚óè Use bulk actions to speed up the process where applicable
What you need
‚óè Access to your Google Ads account
‚óè Successful completion of:
‚óã Our initial search ads project
‚óã Our keyword project
Introduction
In this project, you‚Äôll create ads for your Google Ads campaign(s), enabling you to
launch them and measure performance.

We‚Äôre adopting a modern, streamlined approach with one or more campaigns
containing ad groups targeting three key concepts:

‚óè High Intent Searches : Users ready to buy or engage (e.g., branded terms,
specific product queries).
‚óè Problem-Solution Searches : Users seeking answers to pain points your
product solves.
‚óè Competitors : Users searching for rival brands or solutions.
Each ad group‚Äôs copy will align with its targeting focus. With RSAs, you‚Äôll input multiple
headlines (up to 15) and descriptions (up to 4) per ad, letting Google dynamically test
and optimize combinations. Aim for 10‚Äì15 headlines and 3‚Äì4 descriptions per RSA to
maximize flexibility.

To start, draft your copy directly in the Google Ads interface to preview it in context.
Optionally, save it in a Google Doc for feedback and future reference. Let‚Äôs dive in.

How to Create an Responsive Search Ad
In Google Ads, go to All Campaigns > Ads & Assets > Ads.
Click the blue + > + Responsive Search Ad.
Select your campaign and ad group.
Enter your copy:
‚óã Headlines : 10‚Äì15 variations (e.g., ‚ÄúEcoClean ‚Äì Green Cleaning,‚Äù ‚ÄúNatural
Detergent by EcoClean‚Äù).
‚óã Descriptions : 3‚Äì4 variations (e.g., ‚ÄúDiscover EcoClean‚Äôs sustainable
cleaning products.‚Äù).
Pin brand-specific headlines to Position 1 (hover over the headline, click the pin
icon) if desired.
Add your Business Name and Logo
Add any relevant Ad Assets
Save the ad.
It should look something like this:

Phase 1: Write Ads for High Intent Searches
High Intent ad groups target users with clear purchase or engagement intent‚Äîoften
your brand name, product names, or specific services.

Tailor your RSAs to these keywords for relevance and Quality Score boosts.

Example: Service-Focused Ad Group

For a startup like ‚ÄúEcoClean‚Äù (offering sustainable cleaning supplies), target terms like:

‚óè Sustainable Detergent
‚óè eco-friendly cleaner
‚óè best eco-friendly cleaner
Tips:

‚óè Include service-specific keywords in headlines and descriptions for relevance.
‚óè Highlight local availability, expertise, or unique benefits (e.g., ‚ÄúTrusted Local
Landscapers‚Äù).
‚óè Keep copy clear and concise‚Äîavoid overstuffing keywords, focusing on user
intent.
Example RSA for EcoClean

‚óè Headlines:
‚óã EcoClean ‚Äì Green Cleaning
‚óã Sustainable Detergent Online
‚óã Trusted Eco-Friendly Cleaner
‚óè Descriptions:
‚óã EcoClean offers natural cleaning products for a greener home.
‚óã Shop sustainable solutions trusted by eco-conscious households.
‚óè Path: /green-cleaning
Start with 1‚Äì2 RSAs per ad group to test messaging while consolidating impressions.

Phase 2: Write Ads for Problem-Solution Searches
These ad groups target users searching for solutions to specific problems your product
addresses. Focus on pain points and benefits rather than brand terms alone.

Example: Problem-Solution Ad Group

For EcoClean, target terms like:

‚óè Eco-friendly stain remover
‚óè Non-toxic cleaner for kids
‚óè Sustainable cleaning alternatives
Tips:

‚óè Address the problem (e.g., ‚ÄúTough Stains?‚Äù) and solution (e.g., ‚ÄúTry Our Natural
Formula‚Äù).
‚óè Use benefit-driven language (e.g., ‚ÄúSafe for Families‚Äù).
Example RSA

‚óè Headlines:
‚óã Tough Stains? Go Green
‚óã Non-Toxic Cleaning Power
‚óã EcoClean Solves Messes
‚óè Descriptions:
‚óã Remove stains with EcoClean‚Äôs safe, natural formula.
‚óã Clean sustainably without harmful chemicals.
‚óè Path: /natural-solutions
Phase 3: Write Ads for Competitor Searches
Competitor ad groups target users searching for rival brands. You can bid on their
keywords but cannot use their names in ad copy (to avoid trademark issues). Be
subtle and strategic.

Example: Competitor Ad Group

If EcoClean competes with ‚ÄúCleanWorks‚Äù and "GreenWorks" target terms like:

‚óè GreenWorks alternative
‚óè Cleanworks alternative
‚óè Cleanworks eco-friendly
Tips:

‚óè Echo competitor terminology (e.g., ‚Äúplant-based‚Äù if they use it).
‚óè Highlight differentiation (e.g., price, features, or unique benefits like ‚Äú100%
Plastic-Free‚Äù).
‚óè Take shots at the enemy's weakness (chemicals vs all natural)
Example RSA

‚óè Headlines:
‚óã Ditch the chemicals
‚óã All natural cleaner
‚óè Descriptions:
‚óã Switch to a 100% plastic-free, natural cleaner today.
‚óã Cleaner homes with eco-friendly power‚Äîshop now.
‚óè Path: /eco-alternative
Phase 4: Create the Ads in Google Ads
Continue this process for all your campaigns and ad groups.

Make sure your ads are still paused just in case!

Final Notes
‚óè How how many ads per ad group? Start with 1‚Äì2 RSAs per ad group to test
messaging efficiently, especially with a modest testing budget. Scale to 3 only if
impression volume supports it later.
‚óè Ad strength: Aim for ‚ÄúGood‚Äù or ‚ÄúExcellent‚Äù by varying headlines and including
keywords naturally.
Okay, now to dive a little bit into Google's targeting options.

Google Ads Targeting and Structuring
What you‚Äôll learn
‚óè The targeting options available for campaigns and ad groups, and how to use
them effectively.
‚óè Recommendations for structuring campaigns and ad groups to maximize
performance.
Introduction
How you structure your Google Ads campaigns and ad groups depends on your:

‚óè Keyword themes,
‚óè Targeting goals, and
‚óè Budget.
This lesson explores the targeting options available and provides a streamlined, modern
approach for structuring your account‚Äîperfect for a startup testing Google Ads.

While targeting can feel complex, we‚Äôll keep it simple and actionable for beginners.

Campaign Targeting
At the campaign level, you can target two primary options: locations and languages.
These settings shape who sees your ads and are interconnected.

Locations
‚óè Why it matters : Targeting the right locations ensures you reach potential
customers while avoiding wasted spend on irrelevant areas.
‚óè For ecom or local businesses : If you sell physical products or services in
specific regions (e.g., the United States), target only those countries, states, or
cities where you operate.
‚óã See the bullet point below about "People In vs People Interested In"
‚óè For SaaS or global products : If your product can be used worldwide (e.g., a
$1,000/month SaaS tool), consider targeting ‚ÄúTier 1‚Äù and ‚ÄúTier 2‚Äù markets‚Äîmajor
English-speaking countries (US, UK, Canada, Australia, New Zealand),
Scandinavia (Sweden, Norway, Denmark), Western Europe (Germany, France,
Netherlands), and parts of Eastern Asia (e.g., Singapore, Hong Kong). Avoid
low-conversion regions like Latin America, Africa, India, etc, unless you have
data showing viability.
‚óè Targeting states and cities : If you're spending >$10k per month, you should
target specific states, provinces, or major cities (e.g., US states, Canadian
provinces, London, Paris) to analyze performance by region. Use Google Ads‚Äô
location reports to refine spending later.
‚óã Do that by choosing Enter another location and adding them in
separately.
‚óè People In vs. People Interested In :

‚óã Default: ‚ÄúPresence or interest‚Äù includes users in your target location or
those showing interest (e.g., researching a trip or reading about the area).
‚óã Recommendation : Set to ‚ÄúPresence: People in or regularly in your
targeted locations‚Äù to target only people who are actually in that space,
reducing irrelevant clicks. You‚Äôll miss some travelers or unlocatable users,
but this trade-off improves efficiency.
‚óè Excluding locations : Exclude areas where you can‚Äôt or won‚Äôt serve (e.g., Alaska
or Hawaii for a US-based product unavailable there). Use ‚ÄúPeople in your
excluded locations‚Äù to avoid targeting researchers or travelers from those areas.
‚óã To exclude, you need to do Enter another location then type the location
and select Exclude
Languages
Language targeting is generally based on the language the user‚Äôs computer or browser
is set to‚Äînot necessarily the languages they speak or understand.

This means Google targets users based on device or browser settings, which can
sometimes lead to mismatches (e.g., a non-English speaker using an English browser
might see English ads).

‚óè Why it matters : Language targeting ensures your ads match users‚Äô language
preferences, improving relevance and conversions.
‚óè Modern approach : Use ‚ÄúAll languages‚Äù for high-English-fluency countries (e.g.,
US, UK, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Netherlands, Sweden, Norway,
Denmark) if your ads and landing pages are in English. Non-English speakers in
these regions often use English fluently and convert well.
‚óè For lower-English-fluency countries : Target only English (e.g., Germany,
France, South Korea, Finland, Switzerland, Singapore, Hong Kong, Israel) unless
you have multilingual ads and landing pages.
‚óã To do that, you'll need to create a separate campaign from your main
ones.
‚óè Avoid overcomplicating : Don‚Äôt create separate campaigns for each language
unless you have a very large budget and proven ROI from Google Ads‚Äîand if
your site/product also tailors to that language. Google‚Äôs data shows English-only
targeting performs well in high-fluency regions, simplifying management.
Campaign and Ad Group Targeting
Beyond campaigns, you can refine targeting at the ad group or campaign level with
these options:

Audiences/Remarketing Lists
‚óè Target specific audiences (e.g., website visitors, past customers, or in-market
segments) to reach users more likely to convert.
‚óè Use Google Ads‚Äô audience suggestions (e.g., ‚ÄúHome & Garden‚Äù for landscaping
services) or custom remarketing lists (e.g., users who visited your pricing page).
‚óã You can either "target" or "observe" these audiences. We recommend
setting it to Observe for now, which will let you see the relative
performance. If one under- or over-performs, act accordingly.
‚óè Keep it simple for beginners‚Äîstart with broad in-market or affinity audiences,
then refine based on performance.
Devices
‚óè Target desktops, mobile phones, or tablets, but note: You can‚Äôt exclude devices
entirely‚Äîyou must adjust bids (e.g., ‚ÄúDecrease by 100%‚Äù to exclude).
‚óã Use device bid adjustments (e.g., +20% for mobile if conversions are
higher) rather than strict exclusions. Google‚Äôs machine learning often
handles device optimization effectively, especially with Smart Bidding
(e.g., Target CPA or Maximize Conversions).
‚óè You can‚Äôt target by operating system (e.g., iOS, Android) or browser, but address
this in ad copy (e.g., ‚ÄúDownload our iOS app now‚Äù).
‚óè Oddly you get there by going Insights and reports then When and where ads
showed
Ad Schedules
‚óè Google automatically analyzes performance by day of the week and hour of day.
Use this data to adjust bids for high-performing times (e.g., +20% during
weekdays for B2B products).
‚óè Avoid custom schedules unless you have clear data showing specific times
outperform (e.g., work hours for B2B) or for whatever reason your product
shouldn't be promoted at certain times. For startups, leave schedules
open‚Äîintent-based searches can occur anytime, even at 3 a.m. on weekends.
Demographics (Gender, Age, Household Income)
In the Audiences, keywords, and content -> Audiences you can edit a few things
including the demographics targeted on specific ad groups.

‚óè Gender : Target ‚ÄúFemale,‚Äù ‚ÄúMale,‚Äù or ‚ÄúUnknown‚Äù (e.g., untracked, minors, or
non-binary users). Start broad (all genders) unless your product is clearly
gender-specific (e.g., exclude men for feminine hygiene products). Optimize later
based on data.
‚óè Age : Target ranges like 18‚Äì24, 25‚Äì34, 35‚Äì44, 45‚Äì54, 55‚Äì64, 65+, or ‚ÄúUnknown.‚Äù
For most products, focus on 25‚Äì54 (the ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù for spending power and
tech adoption). Exclude 18‚Äì24 (low conversion rates) and 55+ (less likely to
adopt new tech online) unless your product targets those groups.
‚óè Household Income : Use categories like ‚ÄúLower 50%,‚Äù ‚ÄúTop 41‚Äì50%,‚Äù etc. Start
broad unless your product is niche or expensive (e.g., exclude ‚ÄúLower 50%‚Äù for a
luxury product). The 11‚Äì50% range often performs best for mass-market or
mid-range products.
Campaign Structuring
Modern Google Ads structuring prioritizes simplicity, scalability, and Google‚Äôs
automation.

Here‚Äôs how to structure campaigns and ad groups for a startup testing the channel:

Why create separate campaigns?
Different budget needs : Separate campaigns for distinct goals (e.g., High Intent
Searches, Problem-Solution Searches, Competitors) to control budgets
independently. Google allocates your daily budget across a campaign‚Äôs ad
groups, so splitting ensures no single keyword or location overspends (e.g., India
dominating due to high volume).
Unique targeting : Use separate campaigns for different locations, languages, or
demographics if they require distinct strategies (e.g., US vs. UK, English vs.
non-English regions). However, keep it simple for beginners‚Äîstart with one
campaign covering key markets.
Testing strategies : Create separate campaigns to test bidding strategies (e.g.,
Target CPA for conversions, Maximize Clicks for traffic) or ad formats (e.g., RSAs
vs. Performance Max).
Ad group structuring
‚óè Tight themes : Group keywords by intent and theme within ad groups (e.g.,
‚Äúlandscaping services,‚Äù ‚Äúlandscaper near me‚Äù for High Intent). Use 5‚Äì15 closely
related keywords per ad group to maintain relevance and Quality Score.
‚óè Avoid SKAGs : Single Keyword Ad Groups are an outdated thing. Modern
accounts group broad match keywords into tight themes and use Responsive
Search Ads, letting Google‚Äôs machine learning optimize dynamically.
Examples

You could either create one big campaign like we suggested earlier, or you can break
the different ad group types into separate campaigns so you can have several ad
groups and control the budgets.

That could look

‚óè Campaign 1: Landscaping Services (High Intent)
‚óã Ad Group 1: ‚ÄúLandscaping Services‚Äù (keywords: landscaping services,
professional lawn care, yard maintenance).
‚óã Ad Group 2: ‚ÄúLocal Landscapers‚Äù (keywords: landscaper near me, local
lawn care, nearby landscaping).
‚óè Campaign 2: Problem-Solution Searches
‚óã Ad Group 1: ‚ÄúLawn Maintenance‚Äù (keywords: lawn maintenance services)
‚óã Ad Group 2: "Fix Dying Lawn" (keywords: fix patchy lawn, lawn restoration
services, green lawn tips).
‚óè Campaign 3: Competitors
‚óã Ad Group 1: ‚ÄúCompetitor Alternatives‚Äù (keywords: better than [Competitor
X], [Competitor X] alternative, eco-friendly landscaping).
Keeping it simple for startups

‚óè Start with 1‚Äì2 campaigns covering your key markets (e.g., US, CA) and intent
types (High Intent, Problem-Solution, Competitors).
‚óè Target ‚ÄúAll languages‚Äù or English in high-fluency regions and focus on key
states/cities.
‚óè Use broad demographics (25‚Äì54, all genders, 11‚Äì50% income‚Äîunless you
target even more broadly than that) initially, narrowing based on data.
‚óè Don‚Äôt split into dozens of campaigns upfront‚Äîtest with either one campaign, or
single campaign per intent type, then expand as you scale and prove ROI.
‚óè Use Smart Bidding (e.g., Target CPA, Maximize Conversions) to let Google
optimize bids dynamically across devices, times, and locations.
Okay, now with that, you understand the targeting options

Google Ads Audiences
What You‚Äôll Do
‚óè Learn what remarketing lists (now called ‚Äúaudience lists‚Äù in Google Ads) are and
the types available.
‚óè Understand how to use them effectively across Search, Display, and
Performance Max campaigns.
‚óè Create audience lists and add them to your campaigns.
Introduction
In Google Ads, the Audiences tab allows you to create and manage audience lists
(formerly remarketing lists) to target or exclude specific groups of people based on their
interactions with your website, app, YouTube channel, or search behavior. These
interactions include actions like signing up for your mailing list, making a purchase, or
visiting key pages, as well as how recently they performed those actions (e.g., 30, 60, or
365 days).

Audience lists enable you to:

‚óè Exclude current or past customers to avoid wasting ad spend on people who
already know you.
‚óè Retarget unconverted visitors or past customers with tailored ads across Search,
Display, or YouTube.
‚óè Prospect for new customers similar to your best audiences using ‚ÄúSimilar
Audiences‚Äù or ‚ÄúCustom Audiences.‚Äù
‚óè Optimize bids and targeting for high-value users, leveraging Google‚Äôs
automation.
While audience lists are powerful for Display and YouTube campaigns, they‚Äôre also
valuable for Search and Performance Max campaigns, especially for exclusions and bid
optimization. Before launching ads, set up audience lists to target the right people
efficiently.

Note: You can‚Äôt access personally identifiable information about users on these
lists‚Äîthey‚Äôre used solely for targeting purposes.

Let‚Äôs explore the types of audience lists and how to use them effectively.

Types of lists
Google Ads offers several ways to create audience lists, most of which are
automatically generated. You can set how long a user remains on a list (e.g., 30 days,
90 days, or unlimited). Here are the main types:

1. Website Visitors (Based on URL or Pages)

‚óè How It Works : Automatically create lists of users who visit specific pages on
your website (e.g., /cart, /checkout, /confirmation, /pricing).
‚óè Best Use : Target or exclude users based on their website behavior, such as
visitors who viewed your pricing page but didn‚Äôt convert.
‚óè Tip : Use Google Tag Manager or the Google Ads tag to track page visits. Avoid
relying solely on URLs, as they can change‚Äîuse events or conversions for
reliability (see ‚ÄúConversion Events‚Äù below).
‚óè Membership Duration : Set a duration (e.g., 30‚Äì365 days) based on how long
users remain relevant (e.g., 30 days for cart abandoners, 100+ days for
purchasers‚Äîdepending on product).
2. Conversion Events (Preferred for Automation)

‚óè How It Works : Automatically generate lists of users who complete specific
conversion actions you‚Äôve defined (e.g., purchases, sign-ups, form submissions).
‚óè Best Use : This is the easiest and most reliable method for creating retargeting
lists, especially for future customers. It integrates seamlessly with Google
Analytics 4 (GA4) or Google Ads conversion tracking.
‚óè Tip : Use GA4 events or Google Ads conversion goals to track actions like
‚ÄúPurchase‚Äù or ‚ÄúAdd to Cart,‚Äù then create audience lists based on these events.
This is more accurate than manual tags and scales easily.
‚óè Membership Duration : Set based on your product and customer lifecycle (e.g.,
30 days for cart abandoners, 100+ days for purchasers‚Äîdepending on product).
3. App Users

‚óè How It Works : Automatically create lists of users who have downloaded or
interacted with your mobile app (e.g., installed, made an in-app purchase).
‚óè Best Use : Target or exclude app users for app install campaigns, retargeting, or
cross-channel promotions (e.g., pushing app users to your website).
‚óè Tip : Use Firebase or Google Ads app tracking to set up these lists, ensuring
accurate attribution across devices.
4. YouTube Users

‚óè How It Works : Automatically generate lists of users who watched videos on your
YouTube channel (e.g., viewed 25% or more of a video, subscribed).
‚óè Best Use : Retarget YouTube viewers with Display, YouTube, or Search ads, or
exclude converted viewers.
‚óè Tip : Combine with Performance Max or Video campaigns for broader reach.
5. Customer Lists (For Current/Past Users)

‚óè How It Works : Upload a list of customer data (e.g., email addresses) to match
with Google accounts. You can set a membership duration (e.g., 30 days, 60
days, or unlimited).
‚óè Best Use : Exclude current or past customers from campaigns to avoid redundant
ad spend, or retarget lapsed customers (e.g., those who haven‚Äôt purchased in
90+ days).
‚óè Limitations : This list doesn‚Äôt update automatically‚Äîyou must manually refresh it
with new data or rely on conversion-based lists for ongoing tracking.
‚óè Tip : Use Google Ads‚Äô Customer Match feature, which supports email, phone
numbers, or mailing addresses, and integrates with GA4 for better automation.
6. Similar Audiences (Lookalike Audiences)

‚óè How It Works : Google automatically creates lists of users with behaviors and
interests similar to your existing audience lists (e.g., customers, converters, or
website visitors).
‚óè Best Use : Prospect for new customers in Display, Search, or Performance Max
campaigns, as these audiences often convert well due to Google‚Äôs extensive
data.
‚óè Tip : Combine with in-market or affinity audiences for even better results, and use
Smart Bidding to optimize bids for these segments.
How to use Audient Lists effectively
Audience lists are versatile and can enhance performance across Search, Display,
YouTube, and Performance Max campaigns.

Here‚Äôs how to use them strategically, with a focus on automation and modern practices:

Search
‚óè Exclude converted users
‚óã Avoid paying for clicks from current or past customers who already know
your brand. Use a combination of customer lists (uploaded emails) and
conversion-based lists (e.g., ‚ÄúPurchased in the last 30 days‚Äù) to exclude
these users.
‚óã Focus on key conversion events like purchases or sign-ups. For
unconverted users (e.g., cart abandoners), keep showing ads to drive
them back‚Äîdon‚Äôt exclude them yet.
‚óã Tip : Use ‚ÄúObservation‚Äù mode initially to track performance, then switch to
‚ÄúTargeting‚Äù (exclude) if data shows savings without losing conversions.
‚óè Optimize bids for high-value audiences
‚óã Use audience lists to bid higher on users more likely to convert,
such as website visitors who didn‚Äôt convert or users deep in your
funnel (e.g., ‚ÄúAdded to Cart‚Äù).
‚óã With Smart Bidding (e.g., Target CPA, Maximize Conversions),
Google automatically adjusts bids for these audiences based on
performance‚Äîno manual bid increases (e.g., 25‚Äì50%) needed.
‚óã Set membership durations (e.g., 30 days for recent visitors, 90 days
for cart abandoners) to keep lists relevant.
Display/YouTube
‚óè Exclude converted users
‚óã Same as Search‚Äîexclude current customers or recent converters to save
budget. Use customer lists or conversion-based lists (e.g., ‚ÄúPurchased >
30 days ago‚Äù).
‚óã Tip : Combine with frequency capping to limit ad exposure to these users.
‚óè Run retargeting campaigns for unconverted visitors
‚óã Target website visitors, YouTube viewers, or app users who didn‚Äôt convert
with tailored Display or YouTube ads. Offer incentives like discounts or
reminders (e.g., ‚ÄúComplete Your Purchase Today‚Äù).
‚óã Break into segments for precision, such as:
‚ñ† <30-day website visitors who didn‚Äôt sign up or purchase.
‚ñ† 31‚Äì60-day visitors who abandoned carts.
‚óã Use Smart Bidding to optimize bids, and test ad formats (e.g., responsive
display ads, video ads) for engagement.
‚óè Retarget lapsed customers
‚óã Create lists of customers who haven‚Äôt engaged or purchased recently
(e.g., >45 days for a product bought monthly). Retarget with Display or
YouTube ads to re-engage them.
‚óã Example : For a landscaping service, retarget customers who haven‚Äôt
booked maintenance in 60+ days with seasonal offers.
‚óè Prospect with "Similar Audiences"
‚óã Use ‚ÄúSimilar Audiences‚Äù to reach new users with behaviors like your best
customers. Combine with in-market or affinity audiences for broader
reach.
‚óã Tip : Test in Performance Max campaigns for cross-channel optimization
(Search, Display, YouTube, Discover).
For Performance Max Campaigns
‚óè Leverage All Audience Types :
‚óã Use website visitors, conversion events, customer lists, and similar
audiences to refine targeting within Performance Max campaigns, which
span Search, Display, YouTube, and more.
‚óã Exclude converted users and bid higher on high-value segments (e.g., cart
abandoners, past visitors) using Smart Bidding.
‚óã Tip : Performance Max automatically optimizes across audiences, so use
‚ÄúObservation‚Äù mode initially, then refine based on performance data.
How to Create and Add Audience Lists
to Campaigns
Follow these steps to set up and apply audience lists in Google Ads:

1. Create Audience Lists

‚óè Go to Audiences :
‚óã In Google Ads, click Tools & Settings > Shared Library > Audience
Manager.
‚óã Click the blue + button to create a new audience.
‚óè Choose a Type :
‚óã Website Visitors : Select ‚ÄúWebsite visitors‚Äù and specify URLs or use
Google Analytics events (e.g., ‚ÄúVisited /cart‚Äù).
‚óã Conversion Events : Use tracked conversions (e.g., ‚ÄúPurchase,‚Äù
‚ÄúSign-Up‚Äù) to auto-generate lists.
‚óã Customer Lists : Upload a CSV or use Customer Match with emails,
phone numbers, or addresses.
‚óã App Users/YouTube Users : Select the relevant platform and define
actions (e.g., ‚ÄúWatched 25% of video‚Äù).
‚óã Similar Audiences : Let Google create lists based on existing audiences.
‚óè Set Membership Duration :
‚óã Choose how long users stay on the list (e.g., 30 days for recent visitors,
180 days for customers).
‚óè Save the Audience :
‚óã Name the list (e.g., ‚ÄúCart Abandoners ‚Äì 30 Days‚Äù) and save it.
2. Add Audiences to Campaigns

‚óè Campaign or Ad Group Level :
Go to the campaign or ad group > Audiences tab.
Click the blue + button to add audiences.
Select your created lists (e.g., ‚ÄúCart Abandoners,‚Äù ‚ÄúPast Customers‚Äù).
Choose ‚ÄúTargeting‚Äù (show ads only to these audiences) or ‚ÄúObservation‚Äù
(track performance but show ads to everyone).
Save changes.
3. Monitor and Optimize
‚óè Use the Audiences report in Google Ads to analyze performance (e.g.,
conversions, cost, CTR) by audience segment.
‚óè Adjust targeting or bidding after 30‚Äì60 days based on data, or let Smart Bidding
optimize automatically.
Tips
‚óè Start simple : For a budget under $10K/month, create 2‚Äì3 key audience lists
(e.g., ‚ÄúWebsite Visitors ‚Äì 30 Days,‚Äù ‚ÄúPurchased ‚Äì Exclude,‚Äù ‚ÄúSimilar to
Customers‚Äù) and use ‚ÄúObservation‚Äù mode to track performance without restricting
traffic.
‚óè Leverage automation : Use Smart Bidding (e.g., Target CPA, Maximize
Conversions) to optimize bids for audiences dynamically, reducing manual
adjustments.
‚óè Focus on high-value segments : Prioritize lists like cart abandoners, pricing
page visitors, or lapsed customers, as they‚Äôre more likely to convert with
retargeting.
‚óè Integrate with GA4 : Use Google Analytics 4 to track events and create audience
lists automatically, syncing with Google Ads for better accuracy.
Now get to implementing!
Project: Launch!
Overview

Now that you‚Äôve created a paused Google Ads campaign with multiple ad groups, and
learned about keywords, ad copy, targeting, audiences, and optimization strategies, it‚Äôs
time to launch your campaign and start driving results.

This project guides you through activating your campaign, setting an initial budget,
choosing a bidding strategy, and monitoring early performance to ensure a successful
launch testing Google Ads.

Phase 1: Prepare to launch your campaign
Before launching, ensure your campaign is fully configured and paused:

‚óè Verify all ad groups, keywords (using Broad Match), Responsive Search Ads, ad
assets (extensions), targeting (locations, languages, audiences), and conversion
tracking are set up as learned in previous lessons.
‚óè Double-check negative keywords and audience exclusions (e.g., exclude
converted customers) to minimize wasted spend.
‚óè Confirm your landing pages are live, relevant, and mobile-friendly, especially for
high-intent searches like ‚Äúlandscaping services‚Äù or ‚Äúlandscaper near me.‚Äù
Phase 2: Set your budget and bidding strategy
Choose a budget and bidding approach that aligns with your startup‚Äôs goals and
constraints.

Budget guidance

‚óè Initial test budget : Allocate $2,000‚Äì$5,000 for a 30‚Äìto 60-day test to evaluate
profitability across your campaign and ad groups. This ensures sufficient data
(e.g., 50+ conversions) for Google‚Äôs machine learning to optimize effectively.
‚óè Daily budget : Set a daily budget based on your total test amount (e.g.,
$67‚Äì$167/day for a $2,000‚Äì$5,000 monthly budget).
‚óã Note: the more campaigns, products, ad groups, keywords, and locations
you test, either the more budget you need, or the longer you'll need to test,
as you'll be spreading the budget over more variables.
‚óã Note: the more expensive your product is or the longer your sales cycle,
the more budget you'll need or the longer you'll need to test.
‚óè Scalability : If ads prove profitable (or promising) don't just double or triple the
budget suddenly or else you'll risk spiking CPAs and tanking ROAS.
‚óã Instead, scale the budget by 20-50% every 14-30 days. If your initial
budget is $3,000/month ($100/day), scale to $3,600‚Äì$4,500/month
($120‚Äì$150/day) after 30 days of profitability (e.g., CPA $45, ROAS
350%).
‚óã Avoid exceeding 50% at once to prevent overspending on untested
segments‚Äîmonitor CPA and ROAS closely.
Bidding strategy

‚óè Use Smart Bidding : Select an automated strategy like Target CPA (e.g., $50 if
willing to pay $50 per conversion), Target ROAS (e.g., 300% if aiming for $3
revenue per $1 spent), or Maximize Conversions (to drive as many conversions
as possible within your budget).
‚óã Avoid manual bidding strategies (e.g., Manual CPC, Enhanced CPC), as
they‚Äôre outdated for modern SEM‚ÄîGoogle‚Äôs machine learning optimizes
better with Broad Match and automation.
‚óè Adjust targets later : Start with conservative targets (e.g., higher CPA initially to
gather data), then refine downward after 30‚Äì60 days based on performance.
Phase 3: Launch your campaign
‚óè Activate the campaign :
‚óã In Google Ads, go to Campaigns , select your paused campaign
‚óã Click the campaign status (paused) and set it to Enabled.
‚óã Verify all ad groups, ads, and assets are active and error-free.
‚óè Monitor initial performance :
‚óã Check the campaign daily for the first week to ensure ads serve, budgets
aren‚Äôt overspent, and no technical issues arise (e.g., disapproved ads,
tracking errors).
‚óã Use columns like impressions, clicks, CTR, conversions, and CPA to
monitor early results.
‚óè Avoid over-optimizing : Resist making changes in the first 7‚Äì14 days‚ÄîGoogle
needs time to learn and optimize with Broad Match and Smart Bidding.
Phase 4: Optimize
Now that you're launched, use the next lessons to learn how to optimize them over time!

Project: Prepare to Optimize Google Ads
What you‚Äôll learn
‚óè The procedure to optimize Google Search campaigns over time
‚óè How to evaluate performance
‚óè How to improve performance and save money
‚óè How to use Search Terms to add keywords and negative keywords to your ad
groups
‚óè How to use segmentation to dive deeper into data
What is optimizing Google Ads?
Optimizing Google Ads is the process of selectively turning off or de-prioritizing things
that don‚Äôt work (or don‚Äôt work as well as you‚Äôd like), and adding to (or prioritizing) things
that do work.

This can be:

‚óè Keywords
‚óè Ads
‚óè Assets (extensions)
‚óè Demographics
‚óè Locations
‚óè Devices
‚óè And more
For example: you may find that the keyword "design tool" for your UI design tool is
triggering ads for clothing, building, and stage design tools, so you‚Äôd want to stop
targeting clothing , building , and stage.

You may also find that people in Washington convert twice as well as people anywhere
else in the country, so you may want to prioritize them.

Phase 1: Choose success metrics
Before optimizing, establish clear goals. Answer these questions in a document, notes
app, or spreadsheet:

What conversion metric will you optimize for?

‚óè Identify your primary conversion goal (e.g., sign-up, purchase, upgrade). This
should match the conversion event tracked in Google Ads (set in your tracking
setup).
‚óè If your purchase conversion has a long lag (e.g., weeks or months due to a free
trial or complex sales cycle), use an intermediary metric like ‚Äúsign-up‚Äù or ‚Äúlead
form submission.‚Äù This provides Google with short-term data to optimize toward
(50+ conversions per campaign in 30 days is ideal for Smart Bidding).
‚óè Example: For a landscaping service, optimize for ‚ÄúBooking Confirmation‚Äù if
purchases happen quickly, or ‚ÄúQuote Request‚Äù if the sales cycle is longer.
What‚Äôs your Target Cost Per Conversion/Acquisition (CPA) or Return on Ad
Spend (ROAS)?

‚óè Decide how much you‚Äôre willing to pay per conversion (e.g., $50 CPA for a lead)
or what ROAS you expect (e.g., 300% ROAS, meaning $3 revenue per $1
spent).
‚óè Are you okay with higher costs initially to gather data and optimize, or do you
need profitability immediately? For startups, testing often requires a higher CPA
upfront (e.g., $75‚Äì$100) to learn, then refine downward.
How much are you willing to spend to test Google Ads?

‚óè Budget $2,000‚Äì$5,000 for initial testing to evaluate profitability across ad groups
and keywords. This ensures you gather enough data (e.g., 50+ conversions) to
assess performance confidently.
‚óã You should not expect to make money on this initial testing.
‚óè If that's not feasible, then do a small budget (e.g., < $1,000/month), and focus on
high-intent keywords and key locations to maximize impact.
If ads are profitable (or close to), what‚Äôs your monthly spend target?

‚óè Base this on your payback period (e.g., how long it takes to recoup ad spend
through revenue).
‚óã If you have an ecomm business and payback is instantaneous, you can
scale quick.
‚óã If you have an expensive service or software business and it takes weeks
to months, then scale more slowly.
Phase 2: Configure your columns for
performance insights
To evaluate performance effectively, customize your Google Ads columns for quick,
actionable insights.

‚óè How to modify columns :
‚óã In Google Ads, go to Campaigns , Ad Groups , or Keywords (depending
on your focus).
‚óã Click Columns > Modify Columns.
‚óè Set up key metrics :
‚óã Configure columns to include the following (prioritize based on your
goals):
‚ñ† Impressions : How often your ads are shown.
‚ñ† Clicks : User interactions with your ads.
‚ñ† CTR (Click-Through Rate) : Engagement rate (clicks/impressions).
‚ñ† Conversions : Number of completed conversion actions (e.g.,
purchases, sign-ups).
‚ñ† Cost : Total spend.
‚ñ† Cost/Conv. (CPA) : Cost per conversion‚Äîcritical if optimizing for
non-revenue conversions (e.g., sign-ups).
‚ñ† Conv. Value/Cost (ROAS) : Return on ad spend‚Äîkey if your
conversions log revenue (e.g., $500/booked job).
‚ñ† Conversion Rate : Percentage of clicks that lead to conversions.
‚óè Tailor to your goals :
‚óã If your primary conversion (e.g., ‚ÄúPurchase‚Äù) logs revenue, focus on Conv.
Value/Cost and Conv. Value to maximize ROAS.
‚óã If your conversion (e.g., ‚ÄúSign-Up‚Äù) lacks revenue, prioritize Cost/Conv.
(CPA) and Conversions to minimize cost and maximize volume.
‚óè Use segmentation for deeper analysis :
‚óã Click Segment > Conversions > Conversion Action to break down data
by specific conversion types (e.g., ‚ÄúPurchase,‚Äù ‚ÄúSign-Up‚Äù).
‚óã Segment by other dimensions (e.g., device, location, day of week) to
uncover trends (e.g., mobile converts better on weekends).
As you can see in this example, only the Signup event is recording in Conversions ,
and all others are being recorded under All conv.

All conv will also include the number of View-through conversions (people who
converted after seeing your ad, even if they didn‚Äôt click on it).

Conversions doesn‚Äôt include view-throughs. View-throughs are only relevant for
Display and YouTube ads. In the example above, even though we‚Äôre considering the
Signup conversion to be the most important (because of a long time delay between ad
click and Purchase conversion), we‚Äôre still interested in seeing how many people are
completing each step. It lets us see if there‚Äôs a big drop off in the funnel, and whether
people engage with a specific campaign or keyword.

Phase 3: Evaluate performance (think small and
data-driven)
When reviewing performance, focus on granular data before making broad changes.
Don‚Äôt panic if a campaign spends $500 with no conversions‚Äîdrill down to keywords, ad
groups, or segments.

1. Start at the Keyword Level
‚óã Check the Keywords tab for each ad group. Look at spend,
conversions, CPA, and ROAS for individual keywords.
‚óã Example: If ‚Äúdesign tool‚Äù spends $50 with no conversions but
triggers irrelevant clicks (e.g., clothing or stage design), add
**negative keywords like ‚Äúclothing‚Äù or ‚Äústage.‚Äù

Analyze Ad Groups** :
‚óã Review performance across ad groups (e.g., ‚ÄúLandscaping Services,‚Äù
‚ÄúLandscaper Near Me‚Äù). Pause or adjust underperforming ad groups (e.g.,
CPA > $100, 0 conversions after $200 spent).
‚óã Do this sparingly. Only do this if every keyword in the ad group is
underperforming.
3. Segment Data for Insights :
‚óã Use segmentation (e.g., Segment > Device , Location , Demographics )
to identify trends:
‚ñ† But be careful as it's generally best to let Google's algorithm figure
it out, but if you reach significant spend and trends emerge, it may
be worth manually adjusting bids.
‚ñ† Example: If after lots of spend, California consistently drives
conversions at a $40 CPA while other states average $80 increase
bids or focus budget on California.
4. Check Search Terms :
‚óã Go to Keywords > Search Terms to see what users actually searched for
when triggering your ads.
‚óã Note that Search Terms doesn't show all searches, just some of them, due
to privacy concerns.
‚óã Add high-performing search terms as new keywords (e.g., ‚Äúlocal lawn
care‚Äù if it converts well).
‚óã Add negative keywords for irrelevant terms (e.g., ‚Äúfree landscaping‚Äù if it
doesn‚Äôt align with your paid service).
5. Pause Underperformers : Pause keywords, ads, or ad groups with:
‚óã CPA > target (e.g., >$150 if your target is $50).
‚óã 0 conversions after spending 2‚Äì3x your target CPA (e.g., $150 spent with
no conversions).
‚óã Low CTR (<1%) after 1,000+ impressions.
6. Scale Winners :
‚óã If an ad group is outperforming others, consider moving it its own
campaign so you can increase its budget relative to everything else.
‚óã Test variations (e.g., new headlines, similar keywords) to expand reach
while maintaining profitability.

Phase 4: Use automation for long-term success
Google‚Äôs machine learning is more effective than manual optimization over time.

Follow these steps:

Stick with Smart Bidding :
‚óã Use Target CPA or Target ROAS for campaigns, letting Google adjust
bids dynamically across all segments (keywords, audiences, devices,
locations).
‚óã Remove manual bid adjustments‚Äîthey‚Äôre ignored or counterproductive
with automated strategies.
Monitor Performance Regularly :
‚óã Review performance weekly or biweekly, focusing on conversions, CPA,
and ROAS.
‚ñ† Increase the frequency the more you spend.
‚óã Use the Recommendations tab in Google Ads for automated suggestions
(e.g., add negative keywords, optimize bids).
Expand with Performance Max :
‚óã Once Search campaigns prove profitable, test Performance Max
campaigns to scale across Search, Display, YouTube, and Discover, using
audience lists and automation for broader reach.
Tips for startups
‚óè Start small : With a budget of $2,000‚Äì$5,000, focus on 1‚Äì2 campaigns with 3‚Äì5
ad groups targeting high-intent keywords (e.g., ‚Äúlandscaping services,‚Äù
‚Äúlandscaper near me‚Äù).
‚óè Leverage automation : Use Smart Bidding from day one‚Äîdon‚Äôt rely on manual
strategies like Manual CPC or Enhanced CPC, which are outdated for most
accounts.
‚óè Wait for data : Allow 30‚Äì60 days (or 50+ conversions per campaign) before
making major changes. Google needs time to learn and optimize.
‚óè Prioritize high-intent segments : Focus on locations, devices, and audiences
driving conversions, avoiding low-intent or irrelevant traffic.
Yeehaw!

Project: Optimize Google Ads
Overview
When evaluating your Google Ads campaigns, optimize from the lowest level (search
terms, keywords) to the highest (campaigns). Pausing a poorly performing campaign
might seem tempting, but digging deeper often reveals one underperforming keyword
dragging down the rest, leaving profitable opportunities behind.

Here‚Äôs the recommended order for evaluating and optimizing Google Ads:

‚óè Search terms
‚óè Keywords
‚óè Ads
‚óè Ad assets (extensions)
‚óè Audiences (demographics, locations, ad schedules)
‚óè Devices
‚óè Bid strategies
‚óè Ad groups
‚óè Campaigns
Each section below details how to optimize that element and suggests how often to
focus on it. The frequency depends on your impression, click, and conversion volume.
With low volume (e.g., 100 clicks/month across 100 keywords), data accumulation takes
longer‚Äîadjust these guidelines based on your account‚Äôs activity.

Phase 0: Start a log
Before optimizing, maintain a Google Doc or spreadsheet to log major changes and
rationales.

Here‚Äôs an example we used internally for a real client (this example is for Facebook, but
the format is the same).

This helps track performance after adjustments, such as adding negative keywords or
tweaking ad copy. For example:

‚óè Exclude ‚Äústarter kit‚Äù as a negative keyword across campaigns.
‚óã Rationale: We‚Äôve spent $500 with no conversions, and it‚Äôs low-intent.
Phase 1: Search Terms
When: Every time you optimize.

Analyzing search terms is one of the most critical optimization for Google Ads,
especially early in a campaign. It reveals the actual queries triggering your ads, helping
you find new keywords and identify irrelevant searches for negative keywords.

In modern SEM, Google primarily uses Broad Match keywords, relying on its machine
learning to match queries to your ads based on intent, context, and user behavior. For
example, for a UI design tool like Framer, a Broad Match keyword like ‚Äúdesign tool‚Äù

might trigger searches like ‚ÄúUI design software‚Äù or ‚Äúbest design tool for websites‚Äù‚Äîbut
also irrelevant queries like ‚Äúclothing design tool‚Äù or ‚Äútool for designing a building.‚Äù To
stop wasting money on irrelevance, add ‚Äúclothing,‚Äù ‚Äúclothes,‚Äù ‚Äúshirts,‚Äù and ‚Äúbuilding‚Äù as
negative keywords.

You can also reassign high-performing search terms to better-suited ad groups or
campaigns. For instance, if a keyword in a high-intent ad group triggers one that is
better suited for a problem-solution ad group, then add it as a keyword to the other ad
group and add a negative keyword to its current one.

Procedure for finding negative keywords
Navigate to the campaign or ad group you want to optimize.
Set the time range from your last review to today (e.g., last 7‚Äì14 days).
Click Insights and reports > Search terms in the left navigation.
Scroll through the list and select irrelevant queries, such as:
‚óã Searches for entirely different industries or products (e.g., ‚Äúcollege design
program‚Äù for a UI tool, ‚Äúgraphic design program‚Äù if irrelevant, ‚Äúwindows
design program‚Äù if your product is Mac-only).
‚óã Low-intent queries with words like ‚Äúwhat is,‚Äù ‚Äúhow to,‚Äù ‚Äúexample,‚Äù ‚Äúlesson,‚Äù
‚Äúcourse,‚Äù ‚Äútutorial,‚Äù or ‚Äútorrent.‚Äù
‚óã Keywords better suited for different ad groups.
Click Add as negative keyword.
Choose where to add it (e.g., ad group, campaign, or shared negative keyword
list).
‚óã Add broadly (e.g., campaign level) to reduce repetition, but ensure it won‚Äôt
harm other ad groups.
‚óã For account-wide irrelevance, use the ‚ÄúAll Campaigns‚Äù negative keyword
list.
Click Save and repeat for other ad groups.
Procedure for positive keywords
Scroll through the search terms and identify relevant, high-performing queries
(e.g., ‚ÄúUI design tool,‚Äù ‚Äúbest design software‚Äù for Framer).
Use these insights to:
‚óã Update ad copy or landing pages to align with common searches,
improving relevance and Quality Score.
‚óã You probably don't need to worry about adding too many minor keyword
variations as Broad Match dynamically captures them, but do it if they're
quite different and are performing well.
Click Save and repeat for other ad groups.
Phase 2: Keywords
When: Every time you optimize

Continuously refine your Broad Match keywords to focus on winners and pause losers,
leveraging Google‚Äôs automation and data.

Phase 2a: Adjust current keywords
‚óè Review keyword performance over at least the last 14 days using columns like
impressions, clicks, conversions, CPA, and ROAS.
‚óè With automated bidding (e.g., Target CPA, Target ROAS, Maximize
Conversions):
‚óã Let Google handle bid adjustments dynamically‚Äîdon‚Äôt manually adjust
bids.
‚óã Pause Broad Match keywords consistently exceeding your target CPA
(e.g., >$150 if your target is $50) after spending 2‚Äì3x the target CPA (e.g.,
$150 spent with no conversions).
‚óè Use segmentation (e.g., device, location, demographics) to identify
high-performing segments and refine targeting if needed (e.g., increase focus on
mobile if it converts better).
‚óè Avoid pausing keywords too early‚Äîwait for sufficient data (50+
conversions/campaign over 30 days) to ensure confidence in performance.
Phase 2b: Add more keywords/ad groups
If you identify keywords that are performing well that follow a certain trend, consider
breaking it out into its own ad group and tailor the ad copy to the specific keywords.

Or if you identify

Phase 2c: Create new landing pages (optional)
‚óè If certain keywords or ad groups perform significantly better, consider creating
landing pages optimized for those terms (e.g., ‚ÄúLandscaping Services Near Me‚Äù
page).
‚óè Update ad destinations to point to these pages, improving Quality Score,
lowering CPCs, and boosting conversions.
‚óè Monitor performance after changes‚Äînew pages don‚Äôt always outperform existing
ones.
Phase 3: Ads
When: Every time you optimize

Optimize ads by refining ad copy (e.g., Responsive Search Ads) based on performance.
Google prioritizes high-performing ads dynamically, so focus on top performers and
pause underperformers.

Procedure
Select an ad group.
Set the time range to at least 14 days (or between today and your last
optimization).
Click Ads & Assets > Ads.
Filter out paused or removed ads.
Sort by % Served (ascending) to identify poorly performing ads.
Pause ads with <5‚Äì10% served (adjust based on the number of ads
running‚Äîremove those barely shown).
Sort by Cost (descending) to find high-cost, low-conversion ads.
Pause ads if others perform >20% better in conversions or CPA.
Sort by Cost/Conv. (ascending) to identify top performers.
Duplicate top-performing ads and test variations (e.g., new headlines,
descriptions) to improve performance.
Create entirely new ad variations inspired by best performers, focusing on
relevance and intent aligned with Broad Match queries.
Save changes and repeat for other ad groups.
Phase 4: Ad Assets
When: Every month.

Optimize ad extensions (e.g., sitelinks, callouts, structured snippets) at the campaign or
ad group level, as performance varies. Track performance to ensure extensions improve
CPA or ROAS.

Procedure
Go to a campaign or ad group
Change the time range to be at least 30 days
Take note of the average CPA for the campaign/ad group by scrolling down to
bottom and looking at Cost / conv.
Click Assets > Assets in left-nav.
Make note of the average CPA for the extension types by scrolling down to
bottom and looking at Cost / conv.
Pick an Asset type. E.g., Callout. (If it‚Äôs overwhelming to look at all your assets
at once.)
Remove any obvious poor performers (CPA much higher, CTR much lower).
Identify top performers and come up with variations of these top performers and
add them to the campaign/ad group directly.
Repeat for all other asset types you have running.
Repeat for all other campaigns/ad groups.
Phase 5: Audiences
When: Every month.

Optimize audiences (demographics, locations, ad schedules) to focus on
high-performing segments while excluding underperformers. Use Google‚Äôs automation
for efficiency.

Procedure

Select an ad group or campaign (use campaigns for locations, ad groups for
demographics).
Set the time range to at least 30 days.
Navigate to Audiences , Locations , or Ad Schedule in the sidebar.
Analyze performance using CPA, conversions, or ROAS.
With automated bidding (e.g., Target CPA, Target ROAS):
Let Google optimize bids dynamically‚Äîdon‚Äôt manually adjust.
Pause or exclude segments consistently exceeding your target CPA (e.g.,
locations or demographics with no conversions after spending 2‚Äì3x your
target CPA).
Use segmentation to identify trends (e.g., 25‚Äì54-year-olds in California convert
best).
If performance varies drastically (e.g., women 25‚Äì34 convert 50% better),
consider breaking into separate campaigns or ad groups for greater control over
budgets, keywords, and ad copy.
Repeat for all ad groups/campaigns.
Phase 6: Devices
When: Every month.

Optimize device performance, considering website usability if one device underperforms
(e.g., tablets or mobiles).

Procedure

Select an ad group.
Set the time range to at least 30 days.
Click Insights and reporst > When and where ads showed in the sidebar.
Review performance (CPA, conversions, ROAS) for desktops, mobiles, and
tablets.
If a device (e.g., tablets) performs significantly worse, test your landing page on
that device:
1. Check usability (e.g., mobile responsiveness, load speed).
2. Suggest improvements to your team (e.g., optimize for smaller screens, fix
navigation).
If usability isn‚Äôt the issue, optimize normally:
With automated bidding, let Google optimize bids‚Äîpause devices
exceeding your target CPA after sufficient data keeping in mind you're
significantly reducing your total market.
Phase 7: Ad groups
When: Check every time. But do this as a last resort.

If search terms, keywords, ads, and targeting are optimized but an ad group still
underperforms, consider pausing it.

‚óè Review ad group performance (CPA, conversions, ROAS) over 30+ days.
‚óè Pause ad groups with:
‚óã CPA > target (e.g., >$100 if your target is $50).
‚óã 0 conversions after spending 2‚Äì3x your target CPA (e.g., $150 spent).
‚óè Create new landing pages for high-performing ad groups to boost relevance and
Quality Score, then monitor performance.
‚óè Try to determine if there's other ad groups you can launch that you're currently
not targeting.
Again, this should be a last resort and only if all keywords are underperforming in an ad
group.

Phase 8: Campaigns
When: Check every time, but do as last resort.

If all ad groups fail or you want to prioritize better-performing campaigns, pause the
underperforming campaign.

‚óè Review campaign performance (CPA, conversions, ROAS) over 30+ days.
‚óè Pause campaigns with:
‚óã Consistent CPA > target (e.g., >$100 if your target is $50).
‚óã 0 conversions after spending 2‚Äì3x your target CPA (e.g., $1,500 spent on
a $500/day budget).
‚óè Focus budget on profitable campaigns and scale with Performance Max for
broader reach once Search proves viable.
Phase 9: Budgets
Okay, now that you've optimized all the things, here's how to scale your budgets over
time.

1. Confirm profitability and stability (30‚Äì60 days)

‚óè Ensure your initial campaign(s) meets your success metric (e.g., $50 CPA, 300%
ROAS).
‚óè Verify consistent performance across ad groups, keywords, and segments
‚óè Use the Campaigns , Ad Groups , and Keywords reports to confirm 50+
conversions per campaign over 30 days, ensuring Google‚Äôs machine learning
has stabilized.
2. Increase budget incrementally (20‚Äì50% at a time)

‚óè Rule : Increase your daily or monthly budget by 20‚Äì50% every 14‚Äì30 days,
depending on performance.
‚óã Example: If your initial budget is $3,000/month ($100/day), scale to
$3,600‚Äì$4,500/month ($120‚Äì$150/day) after 30 days of profitability (e.g.,
CPA $45, ROAS 350%).
‚óã Avoid exceeding 50% at once to prevent overspending on untested
segments‚Äîmonitor CPA and ROAS closely.
‚óè When to pause : If CPA spikes >20% above target (e.g., >$60 for a $50 target) or
ROAS drops >20% (e.g., <240% for a 300% goal) after scaling, pause the
increase, analyze performance (e.g., Search Terms, devices), and refine (e.g.,
add negative keywords, adjust targeting).
3. Expand targeting strategically

‚óè Locations : Add new high-potential locations (e.g., Texas, Florida) after proving
profitability in key markets (e.g., California). Start with 1‚Äì2 new
states/provinces/countries, scaling 20‚Äì50% of budget there, and monitor for 30
days.
‚óã Example: If California performs at $40 CPA, test Texas with 25% of your
budget ($25/day of $100/day), pausing if CPA exceeds $60.
‚óè Audiences : Expand to similar or in-market audiences (e.g., ‚ÄúHome & Garden,‚Äù
‚ÄúHome Improvement Enthusiasts‚Äù) after proving success with website visitors or
converters. Use ‚ÄúObservation‚Äù mode initially, then switch to ‚ÄúTargeting‚Äù if
performance holds.
4. Test new campaign types (e.g., Performance Max)

‚óè Rule : After 60+ days of profitable Search campaigns, allocate 20‚Äì30% of your
budget to a Performance Max campaign to scale across Search, Display,
YouTube, and Discover.
‚óã Example: With a $5,000/month Search budget, launch a Performance Max
campaign with $1,000‚Äì$1,500/month, targeting the same high-intent
audience (e.g., landscaping) and monitoring for 30 days.
‚óè When to scale : If Performance Max achieves CPA ‚â§ target and ROAS ‚â• goal,
increase its budget by 20‚Äì50% monthly, up to 50% of total spend, while
maintaining Search profitability.
5. Monitor payback period and ROI

‚óè Rule : Scale only if your payback period (time to recoup ad spend via revenue) is
within a timeframe to support your scaling.
‚óã Example: If each $50 CPA conversion yields $500 revenue in 30 days,
scale confidently‚Äîyour ROAS is 1,000%, and payback is immediate.
‚óã If instead, your $500 CPA gives you $1000 in one year, that could get
quite expensive to support scaling over time.
‚óè Pause if unprofitable : If payback exceeds your target (e.g., >60 days), pause
scaling, optimize (e.g., pause underperforming locations, refine Broad Match),
and reassess after 30 days.
6. Cap scaling at sustainable levels

‚óè Rule : Limit total monthly spend to 2‚Äì3x your initial test budget
($4,000‚Äì$15,000/month) until you confirm long-term profitability (e.g., 90+ days
of consistent ROAS >300%, CPA <$50).
‚óã Example: From a $5,000 test budget, scale to $10,000‚Äì$15,000/month
over 3‚Äì6 months, monitoring CPA and ROAS monthly.
‚óè Reassess regularly : Review performance quarterly, adjusting budgets,
targeting, and campaign types based on ROI and market changes.
Tips for startups
‚óè Start small : With a $2,000‚Äì$5,000 budget, test 1‚Äì2 campaigns with 3‚Äì5 ad
groups targeting high-intent Broad Match keywords (e.g., ‚Äúlandscaping services,‚Äù
‚Äúlandscaper near me‚Äù).
‚óè Leverage automation : Use Smart Bidding from day one‚Äîavoid manual
strategies like Manual CPC, which are outdated for most accounts.
‚óè Wait for data : Allow 30‚Äì60 days (or 50+ conversions/campaign) before major
changes. Google needs time to learn and optimize with Broad Match.
‚óè Focus on high-intent segments : Prioritize locations, devices, and audiences
driving conversions, avoiding low-intent or irrelevant traffic by refining Broad
Match with negative keywords.
Search Ads ‚Äì URL Encoding
What you set in your UTM tags is exactly the URL that ads used.

Meaning if you have a space or something in your UTMs, it could break the URL.

To prevent that, you'll want to ‚ÄúURL encode‚Äù it so it doesn‚Äôt break. Essentially, you
replace all spaces and special characters (!$%&@, etc.) with something a browser can
understand.

For example, this URL would break because of the spaces and exclamation point:

https://www.fictitiousdogfood.com/?utm_source=google&utm_campaign=pet
products&utm_medium=search&utm_content=healthiest dog
food!&utm_term=best healthy dog foods

But this one wouldn‚Äôt:

https://www.fictitiousdogfood.com/?utm_source=google&utm_campaign=pet%20p
roducts&utm_medium=search&utm_content=healthiest%20dog%20food%21&utm
_term=best%20healthy%20dog%20foods

Note the %20 (spaces) and %21 (exclamation mark).

So, for example, the utm_campaign of pet products would turn into pet%20products.

How do you encode URLs quickly?

Use this URL encoding tool. Put the name of your campaign (or ad group, or whatever
you‚Äôre trying to encode) in.

Copy-paste the result when you‚Äôre making a URL.

Search Ads ‚Äì Advanced Campaign
Structure Examples
Normal
We always follow this template and structure for our campaigns:

Campaign: Search ‚Äì Core Keywords

‚óè Ad Group 1: High-Intent Purchase Keywords
‚óã Keywords : Broad match terms like ‚Äúbuy [product]‚Äù, ‚Äú[product] pricing‚Äù:
‚ñ† buy grass-fed lamb dog food
‚ñ† high protein dog food for active dogs
‚ñ† best raw lamb dog food
‚ñ† grain-free lamb dog food
‚óã Ad Copy : Strong CTA, price-based offers
‚ñ† Headline 1: "Grass-Fed Lamb Dog Food ‚Äì Free Shipping!"
‚ñ† Headline 2: "High-Protein, Grain-Free ‚Äì Vet Approved"
‚ñ† Description: "Try our all-natural, grass-fed lamb chow. Great for
sensitive stomachs. Order now & get 10% off!"
‚óã Landing Page: Product page or homepage (depending on product)
‚óè Ad Group 2: Problem-Solution Keywords
‚óã Keywords : ‚Äú[problem] solution‚Äù, ‚Äúbest [product] for [use case]‚Äù
‚ñ† best dog food for allergies
‚ñ† dog food for sensitive stomachs
‚ñ† healthy raw diet for dogs
‚ñ† best dog food for coat health
‚óã Ad Copy : Focus on pain points, problem-solving
‚ñ† Headline 1: "Sensitive Stomach? Try Grass-Fed Lamb!"
‚ñ† Headline 2: "Vet Recommended for Allergy-Prone Dogs"
‚ñ† Description: "Our lamb-based formula supports digestion & skin
health. See the difference in 30 days!"
‚óã Landing page: Talk directly to the problem and solution (allergies)
‚óè Ad Group 3: Competitor Terms (Optional)
‚óã Keywords : Competitor brand names + qualifiers like ‚Äúalternative‚Äù
‚ñ† Blue Buffalo lamb dog food alternative
‚ñ† Orijen lamb dog food vs
‚ñ† best Honest Kitchen dog food alternative
‚ñ† is Stella & Chewy‚Äôs good for dogs
‚óã Ad Copy : Positioning against competitors
‚ñ† Headline 1: "Better Than [Competitor]? Try This!"
‚ñ† Headline 2: "Grass-Fed Lamb ‚Äì No Artificial Fillers"
‚ñ† Description: "More meat, no fillers, and healthier digestion.
Compare us to [Competitor] & see why dogs love it!"
‚óã Landing Page : Comparison page
Note: This campaign only has 3 ad groups but it could have more if there are more
specific problem-solution or high-intent searches

More complicated
As discussed we might want to create more campaigns if:

‚óè We want to control the budget more tightly across certain ad groups or locations
‚óè We have a lot of different products
‚óè We want to tailor campaigns to specific languages
‚óè We have a lot of different ad groups and want to couple them more tightly
‚óè We have different conversion goals across different ad groups (purchase vs book
a webinar)
Obviously this could greatly increase the number of campaigns and looks different for
different companies so we won't go into too much detail into one specific type.

Introduction: Performance Max
Overview

Now that you‚Äôve created and launched a standalone Google Search Ads campaign, it‚Äôs
time to explore Performance Max (PMax), Google‚Äôs advanced campaign type that

integrates your Search efforts with Display, YouTube, Shopping, Gmail, and Discover
ads.

This module will guide you through leveraging PMax to enhance conversions, build
brand awareness, and scale efficiently, complementing your Search campaign with
minimal effort. If you need a partner after completing this course, our ads agency can
assist.

Questions answered in this module

‚óè What is Performance Max, and how does it complement my Search Ads?
‚óè Should my startup use Performance Max?
‚óè How do I create effective PMax campaigns?
What is Performance Max?

Performance Max (PMax) is Google‚Äôs most powerful campaign type, using its advanced
AI and machine learning to optimize ads across multiple channels‚ÄîSearch, Display,
YouTube, Shopping, Gmail, and Discover‚Äîbased on your goals (e.g., conversions,
brand awareness).

It's honestly so powerful that we often don't recommend running dedicated Display and
YouTube campaigns unless you have very specific reasons to do so.

If you really want, you can get it create all the assets for you by automatically grabbing
information from your website. Everything here was autogenerated by Google:

And it automatically will generate:

Of course, they might not be the best but it's a great starting point.

Building on your existing Search campaign (e.g., targeting ‚Äúlandscaping services,‚Äù
‚Äúlandscaper near me‚Äù), PMax enhances performance by:

‚óè Search Ads : Reinforces high-intent text ads on Google search results, capturing
users searching for your services.
‚óè Display Ads : Delivers visual banners, images, or videos on websites, apps, and
videos in the Google Display Network (GDN) for brand awareness and
remarketing.
‚óè Shopping Ads : Directly promotes your ecommerce products directly in Google's
properties.
‚óè YouTube Ads : Runs video or skippable ads on YouTube for engagement and
reach, targeting users interested in your industry.
‚óè Gmail and Discover Ads : Shows personalized ads in Gmail inboxes and
Google Discover feeds for broader exposure.
PMax uses Broad Match keywords, Responsive Ads (Search, Display, YouTube), and
Smart Bidding (e.g., Target CPA, Target ROAS) to automate targeting, bidding, and ad
creation, requiring only high-quality assets and clear goals. It complements your Search
campaign by driving lower-intent traffic (Display, YouTube) while maintaining high-intent
conversions (Search).
