How to Find the Right People
Finding the right people to target
If you email the wrong people, they won‚Äôt respond.

So finding the right people is not just critical‚Äîit‚Äôs 90% of the art of cold emailing.

Follow the steps below with a goal of creating a target persona for your email efforts.
The target persona is simply the type of person that you get emails for. Over time, you
can test different target personas against each other and see which perform best. For
example, say you sell HR services. You might start off by emailing CEOs of construction
companies. If that doesn‚Äôt work well, you might try another target persona of founders at
brand-new startups.

Here‚Äôs how you can identify a target persona that will most likely buy from you.

Speak to existing customers
Start by understanding your current customers and the problems they face.

Interview your current customers. Ask:

‚óè What value prop resonates with them most?
‚óè What‚Äôs the biggest improvement they‚Äôve implemented thanks to your solution?
‚óè What got them to purchase from you?
‚óè What other options did they turn down to do business with you?
‚óè How did they hear about you?
‚óè What are their job titles?
Let‚Äôs walk through an example. Say you sell email marketing software to small brick and
mortar business owners. Let‚Äôs walk through the questions we proposed above:

‚óè What value prop resonates with them most?
‚óã They‚Äôre not technical, so they like how easy your product‚Äôs UX is.
‚óè What got them to purchase from you?
‚óã Simplicity of use, and your inexpensive small business pricing tier.
‚óè What other options did they turn down to do business with you?
‚óã They didn‚Äôt like MailChimp‚Äôs lack of features, and Drip was too expensive.
‚óè How did they hear about you?
‚óã Their friend and local small business owner raved about your product over
coffee.
Use their responses to:

Deeply understand their desires.
Create a strategy to locate more people like them and craft messaging to them
accordingly. We‚Äôll cover this below.
Now it‚Äôs one thing to go back and interview customers retrospectively. Great.

But you can also build a system to continuously interview your customers right after
they choose to buy your product. That‚Äôs when they‚Äôre going to be most helpful to you,
since they just hired you to be the solution to a pain point that they were experiencing.

Use the Jobs To Be Done framework for ongoing interviews: Interview people at the
time that they switched to you so you can:

Understand the exact reason they switched to your solution.
Figure out the "job" they are hiring your company's product to do.
The Jobs To Be Done perspective is product agnostic‚Äîit simply focuses on the problem
that the customer is solving, which allows you to reverse engineer great cold emails
(we‚Äôll cover this shortly).

Find customers higher up the ladder of product
awareness
Once you understand your ideal customer, the next step is to find the names and job
titles of people who are as far along the customer journey as possible.

As a refresher, here‚Äôs a picture of the ladder of product awareness, which is a proxy for
a customer journey:

Higher up on the ladder, prospects will fit into one of these categories:

‚óè They‚Äôre choosing between competitors.
‚óè They‚Äôre using a competitor.
‚óè They‚Äôre using a competitor and are dissatisfied with them.
People that fit into the last category are prime targets because:

You already know they‚Äôre motivated to solve the problem that your business
solves‚Äîthey‚Äôve already paid for a solution to that problem.
You know they‚Äôre looking for a reason to move away from their current solution.
Most of the startups we work with don‚Äôt put much thought into how their competitors
acquire customers. Even more problematic, they rarely track what happens to their
customers after they purchase. What problems do customers face?

Let‚Äôs look at an example using Salesforce.

If you use Salesforce, you‚Äôll end up on Trailhead, their tutorial site, at some point. And if
you ever have problems with their product, you‚Äôll start posting in their forums. Or maybe
you‚Äôll seek solutions in a shared slack group.

As a competitor, you can monitor activity of unhappy users. Often you‚Äôll be able to find
their contact information through the forums or in Slack groups (which we‚Äôll show you
how to do below).

Here are some more places where you can find targets that are already working with
your competitors:

‚óè Competitor community slack channels and Facebook groups.
‚óè Identify customer logos from their landing pages.
‚óè Poach names from sales webinars the competitor runs.
‚óè Look at commenters on their YouTube channels.
‚óè Find users in their support forum posts, e.g., Zendesk.
‚óè Track down everyone who tweet-mentions them.
‚óè Grab case study customers and testimonials from their website.
‚óè Track down the people who leave Chrome Store reviews.
‚óè Find third-party review sites like GetApp, TrustRadius, Capterra and find the
names of reviewers. Then use Clearbit to get their contact information.
‚óè Use BuiltWith to profile prospects by the technologies present on their
websites‚Äîyou can set up alerts when tech is added/removed so that you know
when to reach out.
Finding urgent customers
Sometimes you can‚Äôt find enough of your competitors‚Äô dissatisfied customers. That‚Äôs
fine. If you know things like your target customer‚Äôs job title and company size, you can
look them up directly using Clearbit or LinkedIn Sales Navigator.

When you take this approach, think about what would make them urgently want to
purchase your product: Who‚Äôs feeling the most pain?

Look for targets that have just experienced a critical event ‚Äîa problem that came up
that, if not solved by a certain date, something bad will happen.

Was there a huge fire they had to put out? Is there a meeting where people just left the
company? Did they just get put in charge of a massive budget?

You can find people/companies that have recently experienced a critical event. Start by
looking at the trail these targets leave online. Do they:

‚óè Join specific Facebook groups?
‚óè Have a LinkedIn profile?
‚óè Tweet specific keywords?
‚óè Go on Product Hunt?
‚óè Follow certain GitHub projects?
‚óè Have certain HTML in their website?
‚óè Go to certain conferences/attend webinars? There is often an attendee list that
you can get if you email the organizer.
‚óè Have negative Glassdoor reviews? Have their (former) employees recently
changed job titles on LinkedIn?
‚óè Are they running ads on specific platforms?
‚óè Or hiring for certain positions on Angelist?
Search their online trail and compile a list of names and domains for each prospect.
You‚Äôll create messaging that helps them solve their pain point while writing your emails.

How to Find Email Addresses
Getting email addresses
Once you have a rough prospect list. You‚Äôll need to find the email addresses of each
person in your prospect list in order to reach out.

There are two main ways to find emails:

‚óè Publicly available data : know where to find emails on websites or through
databases.
‚óè Email-finding Tools : software that unlocks emails using other profiles or
information.
We‚Äôll skip the basics and assume you‚Äôve already searched ‚Äúcontact us‚Äù and ‚Äúabout‚Äù
sections on your target‚Äôs website and social media accounts without any luck.

Here are the best ways to find email addresses:

‚óè Lookup services
‚óè Guess
‚óè Twitter
‚óè Mailing lists
Lookup services (and how to scale the process)
Email lookup tools are probably the easiest way to find an email address. Think tools
like Clearbit, Hunter.io, and Apollo.io.

Simply feed them a person‚Äôs name and website, and they‚Äôll return an email address for
you.

The best part? This method scales. Here‚Äôs how:

Step 1: Build a spreadsheet of the names and domain names of people you‚Äôre trying to
contact. There are many ways to do so, but here are a few that we like, depending on
the reason for your outreach:

‚óè Sales : Use LinkedIn Sales Navigator to create a list of targets. You can get lists
of people by job title, industry, company size, seniority, and way way more
criteria. Export the list. When you pair this with a tool like Clearbit or Hunter.io,
you can turn LinkedIn data into emails quickly.
‚óè Sales alternative : Manually create the list using the steps we mentioned above
in finding the right people to target.
‚óè Backlinks for content marketing : Use Ahrefs‚Äô Content Explorer to search for
bloggers in your space. Export the file and you‚Äôll have names and domains.
Step 2: Use Hunter for Sheets to utilize Hunter.io‚Äôs email lookup service to get email
addresses for your entire list.

Now you have a targeted list of contacts and emails.

The catch? Even the most effective tools don‚Äôt return perfect results. Expect at least
every tenth email address to be incorrect.

Guess
Email addresses are so predictable that you can often guess and get it right.

Since most email addresses follow a standard format, if you know your target‚Äôs first
name, last name, and domain, you can find the right email.

The most common format is name@domainname.com

Popular formats include:

‚óè First name: nick@demandcurve.com (please don‚Äôt)
‚óè First name and last name: nick.costelloe@demandcurve.com
‚óè First name and initial: nickc@demandcurve.com
‚óè Last name and initial: ncostelloe@demandcurve.com
You can use guessing tools like this or this to generate all possible email addresses.

Once you generate the possible variants (as we did above), you‚Äôll want to validate one
before sending.

So go to Gmail, click ‚ÄúCompose‚Äù and paste all the email variants into the ‚ÄúTo‚Äù field.
Move the cursor over the email address one by one.

A pop-up will show you if the email address is associated with a Google profile.

That‚Äôs the email you want.

If you‚Äôre looking for further validation before you send, simply Google the email address.
If it exists on the web, it‚Äôll return in searches.

This process is a bit time consuming, so consider hiring a freelancer through Upwork or
Fiverr to do this for you and return a list of confirmed emails.

And if you‚Äôre not able to validate particular emails, you could Bcc a number of the
guessed emails you generate.

Another reason to attempt guessing?

If you can find at least one other email from the target company, you can apply that
syntax to your target prospect guess.

Twitter
If your prospects have Twitter accounts, you can leverage Twitter to find their email
addresses.

People occasionally share their emails in tweets, but to keep them hidden from bots,
they replace symbols with words like ‚Äúdot‚Äù and ‚Äúat‚Äù.

So try this:

Go to Twitter Advanced Search.
Search your target person, and include the words ‚Äúat‚Äù and ‚Äúdot.‚Äù
If that doesn‚Äôt work, try the words, ‚Äúemail,‚Äù ‚Äúcontact,‚Äù or ‚Äúreach‚Äù in your search to
narrow down the results.
Another way to leverage Twitter? Reach out to your target directly on Twitter (through a
Tweet or even a DM) and ask for their preferred method of contact. They‚Äôll often prefer
that you reach out to their email address.

Note: This last tactic typically works if you have an active Twitter account and you are
reputable enough that your target is willing to provide their contact information.

Tip from behavioral psychology: When you reach out to people on Twitter first and then
send them an email, they‚Äôre more likely to feel obligated to respond.

Mailing lists
If a person you‚Äôre targeting has an option to subscribe to a newsletter on their website,
sign up for it.

Most email newsletters come directly from their personal email address.

Then all you need to do is reply to one of the newsletter emails with a quick question.

Even if the newsletter is coming from an email address like, ‚Äúhello@domain.com‚Äù or
‚Äúteam@domain.com‚Äù, your target, if they reply to your reply, will likely do so from their
personal email, not a shared email.

Hacks
If you‚Äôre up for a few hacks, try these:

‚óè Going into Facebook groups, cross-referencing the people in them with their
LinkedIn profiles, and using the ContactOut Chrome extension to extract the
email from those profiles.
‚óè Programmatically scraping GitHub for designers who followed specific projects.
‚óè Look in relevant Slack channels (as we indicated in our section on finding the
right people to target). Take the names and companies and run them through
hunter.io to get email addresses.
‚óè Consider purchasing emails wholesale from a reputable vendor (example here).
Once you have a list of emails, run them through a list clearing service like this to make
sure you‚Äôre not sending to incorrect email addresses (which will hurt your email
deliverability‚Äîcovered in this module).

How to Write Emails That Convert
A note on strategy
Archetypes

There‚Äôs a strategy for optimizing your cold email open and response rates:

‚óè Create 2-3 high-level archetypes of emails ahead of time.
‚óè Then A/B test them on a portion of the target emails you‚Äôve collected (~100
emails for each archetype is enough).
‚óè Analyze data to see which email had the best reply rate and call booking rate.
‚óè Then send the winning email to the rest of your list.
Here are two email archetypes. These sell a video tool that helps with meetings and
team collaboration:

For each option, you want to create:

A thesis : The style and tone of the email you want to test. Make sure each thesis
considers what sort of behaviour you‚Äôre trying to drive:
1. ‚ÄúHumble and inquisitive‚Äù tone should drive a booked call from the
prospect.
2. ‚ÄúEducational and value-driven‚Äù tone should drive a click through to a
helpful resource.
3. ‚ÄúStraightforward and honest‚Äù tone could prompt a quick reply.
Subject options : At least 3 different subject lines. Then choose your favorite by
surveying people on your team.
Body copy : The contents of the email.
Consider sending emails from your founder

You should also consider the ‚Äúwho‚Äù behind your email. Are your emails coming from
sales reps? Or your founder?

We‚Äôve found that emails from founders drive action more than those coming from sales
reps. Consider setting up a derivative user account like founder@e.domain.com so that
anyone on your team can send cold emails that look like they‚Äôre coming from your
founder.

Now on to creating great body emails.

Personas
To write great emails, you need to understand who you‚Äôre writing to. Luckily, you‚Äôve
done a lot of the hard work earlier in finding the right people to talk to.

Now it‚Äôs time to dig in and create customer personas. Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll want to know
about your prospect:

‚óè Job title.
‚óè Company size.
‚óè Company location.
‚óè What unique challenge they‚Äôre facing.
‚óè What stage of the buyer‚Äôs journey they‚Äôre at.
‚óè What objections they‚Äôll have that will keep them from buying.
‚óè Who the ultimate decision maker is, if it‚Äôs not them.
‚óè What technology they use
If you haven‚Äôt already interviewed your best 10-50 customers, do that before you craft
your emails.

Use this information to craft compelling subject lines and body copy.

Say your prospect is the owner of a small business with 10 employees and they need
more clients. You could write the subject, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll help you land five more clients this month‚Äù
and create body copy that proves that you did your homework.

Subject line
Subject lines (paired with your domain name) dictate your open rate.

Important: Emails should be measured not just by open rate, but by completion rate on
the desired behavior. Vague or baity subject lines often perform well in terms of open
rate yet fail in terms of conversion. Lower open rates with strong conversion are more
optimal.

Optimize for designed completion rate, not just open rate.

Subject line needs to be:

‚óè Informal : This shouldn‚Äôt feel like a typical cold email. You want to distinguish
yourself from the mass of spam that your prospects get in their inboxes each day.
‚óè Concise : Stick with 50 characters or less so that you also optimize for mobile.
Long subject lines are cut off in most ISPs (like Gmail) on mobile.
‚óè Self-evident : We‚Äôve found that self-evident subjects convert best because
prospects generally don‚Äôt like guessing what your email is about. But it‚Äôs worth
testing slightly opaque subjects if they include sharp hooks and get people to
open and convert.
Subjects need to be relevant to a problem that the reader is currently facing. We
suggest following the guidelines above to start. Then iterate on the versions that
resonate with your audience. Break the rules and see if your open rates and completion
rates are rising.

Good subject lines:

‚óè ‚ÄúLove your work‚Äîwant to feature you in one of our guides‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúA creative way to engage students and employers‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúSeeking advice on [relevant subject]‚Äù
‚óè ‚Äú[Mutual connection] thought we should connect‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúAdvice on making SAAS spending more visible‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúControlling SaaS Spend‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúA Free Facility Management Platform‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúTrending WFH Benefits‚Äù
Bad subject lines:

‚óè ‚ÄúRequest to connect‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúA better way to improve your ROI‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs hop on the phone‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúCheck this out‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúAre you prepared to overcome X?‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúURGENT‚Äù
‚óè ‚ÄúQuick question‚Äù
Body copy
Subject lines get people to open, but it‚Äôs the body content of the email that will get you
replies and booked meetings.

Body copy should do a few things:

Hook the reader
Explain why you‚Äôre reaching out
Predict target customers‚Äô hesitations and objections
Include a personal touch
Include one clear next step
Most importantly, be concise. Try to avoid writing more than 2 sentences per paragraph,
and we‚Äôve found that emails with less than 5 sentences perform best.

Long emails get skimmed. Keep it short and there‚Äôs a better chance prospects will read
it.

Hook the reader

The first sentence means everything‚Äîit determines whether or not the target will read
the rest of your email.

Here are three ways you can hook readers with your first line:

Ask a question to pique interest: Hey {{first.name}}‚Äîcurious if you have to log
into a bunch of different places to manage {{company}}‚Äôs health insurance, 401K,
FSA / HSA, and other benefits?
Address a pain point: Hey {{first.name}}‚ÄîI noticed you work with 6 different
vendors to manage {{company}}‚Äôs adtech. We can help you manage them all in a
single system, if you‚Äôre interested.
Demonstrate clear value: Hey {{first.name}}‚Äîwant to run something by you that
can help you complete {{insert SaaS thing}} in 2-3 days, instead of 2-3 weeks.
Once you‚Äôve hooked them, win them over within a sentence or two.

Indicate why you‚Äôre reaching out

When you send an email to someone who‚Äôs never heard of you before, it‚Äôs important to
explain why you‚Äôre reaching out.

One way to accomplish this is to show the reader that you value what they value:

‚óè I was on your personal site and loved what you wrote about X.
‚óè Just saw your tweet about Y and it made me realize that you‚Äôre interested in [the
thing you offer].
‚óè I listened to your podcast interview about Z and I had a follow up question.
‚óè I was on a call with [person they know] and we thought you‚Äôd be interested in
this.
‚óè Saw you're working on X problem. I‚Äôm also working to improve X.
‚óè I saw you were in the last YC batch and figured I‚Äôd reach out. We were in S19.
‚óè Love the idea behind building a more sustainable and eco-friendly business to
improve the world's wastage.
‚óè XYZ stood out while I was browsing through Instagram and I was so impressed I
wanted to reach out.
Brainstorm 2-3 excuses to cold email individuals. Why would someone in your position,
representing your company, reach out to a specific person?

But avoid coming off as salesy. Avoid things like:

‚óè I see you‚Äôre a sales professional. Me too.
‚óè Given that we both work at agencies, I thought we should connect.
‚óè I just messaged you on LinkedIn, so I figured I should also email you.
This is where you research the person you‚Äôre emailing. Look at their LinkedIn profile,
Facebook profile, personal site, Medium posts, etc. The more you know about them, the
better you can tailor your message.

If you‚Äôre strapped for time, there are virtual assistants that research and write intro
sentences for emails for around $1 USD/per intro‚Äîand they‚Äôre high quality.

Objection handling

Each of your prospects will come armed with objections depending on their stage of the
buyer‚Äôs journey. You should be aware of all possible objections, and have calculated
ways in which you handle them proactively :

Objection : Say your prospects continually fail to convert because they think your
product will cost them too much.

Handling : Subtly indicate that your product either doesn‚Äôt cost more than competitors or
that your product solves their problem in a better way.

Objection : Or say your prospects drop out of the funnel because they think that it would
take too much time to learn about and integrate your product.

Handling : Concisely explain that your product has a short learning curve, and that
integration is seamless.

This is why you surveyed customers earlier: You learned about their key objections and
now you can repurpose them in cold emails.

Your prospect‚Äôs default is to assume that your product is not right for them. You have to
proactively prove that it is.

Make sure you only preemptively handle your biggest objections in cold outreach:

‚óè List your objections in order of severity‚Äîwhich came up most in your surveys?
‚óè Handle the top one or two objections in your emails‚Äîonly the most obvious
ones.
‚óè Leave out anything trivial‚Äîyou don‚Äôt want to raise awareness to objections that
customers didn‚Äôt even know they had.
Lastly, consider using social proof as your objection handling. Most companies won‚Äôt
know who you are, so their first and biggest subconscious objection will be that they
don‚Äôt trust you. Social proof can help targets trust you, quickly. A few social proof ideas
to test:

‚óè Indicate which competitors you‚Äôre already working with.
‚óè Include a one-line testimonial.
‚óè Highlight any relevant names or companies that speak highly of your brand.
‚óè If you‚Äôre seeking an investment with your email, consider including your other
investors.
Personal touch

At some point in your body copy, add a personal touch to indicate to your prospect that
you‚Äôre not spraying and praying‚Äîthat you took the time to learn about them.

You can take one of two approaches:

Keep it relevant to work : Signal to the prospect that they‚Äôre uniquely fit for your
solution.
1. Since I saw that you invest in startups in addition to your role at Demand
Curve, I thought you‚Äôd like this.
2. P.S. we‚Äôre in the X Slack group together. Loved your post on referral
programs.
3. We met back at SXSW in 2018. Really enjoyed our chat about XYZ. Glad
you‚Äôre doing well!
Get personal : Connect through a personal note that‚Äôs unrelated to work. You
might build trust with your prospect. Then they‚Äôll be more likely to buy from you.
1. BTW, saw you played soccer in college. I played at URI. You still playing
these days?
2. One more thing. I saw on your personal site that you make music. I love
music, myself. Actually listened to (name of their song) on spotify. Loved it!
3. [Mutual friend] mentioned you live in SOMA. Even if this isn‚Äôt a fit, let‚Äôs
grab a coffee one of these days!
4. On a personal note, I see you‚Äôre working with Big Brothers Big Sisters. I
volunteer with them myself‚Äîone of my favorite projects.
5. P.S. really liked your blog post on climbing Kilimanjaro. Any adventures on
the horizon for this year?
An addition to signaling that you did your homework before reaching out, consider
asking a question to show genuine interest:

E.g. I read your blog post on X. How did you think of that topic?

Do things that demonstrate that your email isn‚Äôt automated, and you‚Äôre more likely to get
responses.

Tip: You‚Äôll likely have a few critical prospects that require extra personalization. Check to
see if your prospects have social media accounts (Twitter and LinkedIn). Spend a few
minutes on their timeline and get a rough idea about what they‚Äôre interested in. Then
add a subtle note leaning into an interest of theirs. There‚Äôs a high ROI when you take
10-15 minutes to add a meaningful note for your key prospects.

Pick one CTA

Only include one call to action‚Äîthe next step your prospect should take after they read
your email. It should feel natural.

You want a next step that is low enough investment so they don‚Äôt feel like they‚Äôre
rushing into a decision, but compelling enough that they understand how it will help
them solve their problems.

Some examples:

Legal disclaimer

When you send cold emails, make sure you comply with CAN-SPAM rules, which
govern cold emailing in the United States.

(Complying with CAN-SPAM tends to hurt conversion, since it makes cold emails follow
a similar format and people will instinctively screen them out. In particular, having an
‚Äúopt-out‚Äù link immediately makes your email look like spam and can drastically hurt
conversion.)

Consult a lawyer if you want definite legal advice (we can‚Äôt offer it), but they may
recommend following these guidelines at a minimum:

‚óè Don‚Äôt use false or misleading header information
‚óè Don‚Äôt use deceptive subject lines
‚óè Tell recipients where you‚Äôre located with a physical address (this information can
go in your email signature)
‚óè Tell recipients how to opt-out of receiving future email from you.
‚óã This doesn‚Äôt have to be a link. It can be a line in the email asking them to
reply to you directly if they don‚Äôt want any more emails from you.
‚óè Honor opt-out requests promptly.
Examples of Great Cold Emails
You become great at writing cold email campaigns by studying quality cold emails. Here
are 8 strong examples of emails that you can use in your own cold outreach.

A note on body copy: We‚Äôve found that plain text emails convert better than emails that
include other content (e.g. distracting images or HTML). And as you‚Äôll read shortly in our
deliverability section, anything other than plain text will reduce the number of inboxes
that you reach. So keep it simple‚Äîuse text if you can.

1. SaaS Sales
Goal: Book a sales call

Subject: Love your work‚Äîthink we can grow together

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Provides a reason for reaching out : ‚ÄúI see that you‚Äôre using MailChimp‚Äù and
‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident we can improve the revenue you‚Äôre generating from your
newsletter list.‚Äù
‚óè Handles key objection : Julian will immediately wonder 1) if Customer IO truly is
better and 2) if it‚Äôll be more expensive. The email handles both objections by
indicating that 1) many other companies are switching over (social proof) and 2)
that they‚Äôre less expensive than MailChimp.
‚óè Adds personal touch : ‚ÄúI read your writing guide.‚Äù
‚óè One CTA : ‚ÄúGot time for a 15-minute chat...‚Äù is a yes/no question. It‚Äôs the clear
goal of the email.
2. Podcast request
Goal: Get a reply to schedule a podcast appearance

Subject: Morning Brew Podcast (1.5M Listeners)

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Gave a reason for reaching out : Indicates why he‚Äôs reaching out without fluff.
‚óè Handles key objection : Mark Cuban wants a high ROI on his time. Mentioning
1.5M downloads is social proof that handles Mark‚Äôs objection, ‚ÄúIs it worth my
time?‚Äù
‚óè Adds personal touch : ‚ÄúAs someone who read your book when I was growing
up...‚Äù is personal and proves to Mark that the email isn‚Äôt automated. It‚Äôs
thoughtful.
‚óè One CTA : ‚ÄúWould you be down to do a podcast...‚Äù is a yes/no question. It‚Äôs the
clear goal of the email.
3. Investment request
Goal: Book a call to discuss angel investment

Subject: [Company name] x Pre-seed

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Gave a reason for reaching out : Nick indicates that they‚Äôre looking for pre-seed
investment.
‚óè Handles key objection : Any investor will immediately wonder if the startup has
traction. Nick handles the object by mentioning that they have 12,000 members
in a pilot.
‚óè Adds personal touch : ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in the Demand Curve community‚Äù and ‚ÄúYou are one
of three angels I have cold emailed‚Äù are two personal touches that ensure that
the email isn‚Äôt automated.
‚óè One CTA : ‚ÄúIf the above is a fit, let‚Äôs chat‚Äù is a simple CTA that, if effective, will get
Julian to respond so Nick can schedule a call.
‚óè De-risked : ‚ÄúI‚Äôll share my top community building insights...‚Äù de-risks a call. Even
if it doesn‚Äôt work out, there‚Äôs something in it for Julian.
4. Feedback request
Goal: Book a call or get a reply

Subject: Reaching out from S20 - [Sender name]

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Clear reason for reaching out : ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to learn a little more about how teams
use [competitor products]‚Äù
‚óè Handles key objection : Subject line and body (hidden to cover company name)
include ‚ÄúS20,‚Äù indicating that Nick is part of a YC company and is therefore a
vetted entrepreneur. It‚Äôs social proof that handles the objection, ‚ÄúWhy should I get
on the phone with you?‚Äù
‚óè Adds personal touch : ‚Äú...thought this might be a good fit considering that
Demand Curve has a webapp‚Äù includes information about Julian‚Äôs company
which proves that Nick has done research.
‚óè One CTA : Nick asks for a call and links to Calendly. He also offers the alternative
to chat via email, which could be an attractive option that prompts a quicker
response. Calls are often daunting for people. Email is easier. Either way, he‚Äôs
simply requesting a response.
‚óè De-risked : ‚ÄúI can share some tactics that are so insightful you‚Äôll want to use them
for Demand Curve‚Äôs newsletter‚Äù makes the call valuable for Julian.
‚óè A note on linking calendars: You could be a bit more polite and say something
along the lines of, "Please let me know some times that work for you, or if it's

5. Building a portfolio
Goal: Get high quality case studies

Subject: Cold Email As A Service üíå

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Clear reason for reaching out : To provide a free service in exchange for case

‚óè Handles key objection : Andrew is offering a completely free service.
‚óè Adds personal touch : Mentioning that he already has 7 YC companies on

6. Switch from a competitor
Goal: Book a call

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Clear reason for reaching out : The sender saw that the prospect was using a

Subject: thought I‚Äôd reach out, [first name]

Why it‚Äôs great:

organizing virtual corporate events.
‚óè Handles key objection : Including a screenshot of the product de-risks the

‚óè Incorrect‚Äîfails to personalize : If there‚Äôs one area where this email falls short,

Subject: Lunch on me?

Why it‚Äôs great:

‚óè Clear reason for reaching out : They tried reaching out before, and they have a

‚óè Personalization : While this email fails to include a personal note, the tone feels

Sending Cold Emails
Quick note before we dive into sending strategies: You should send yourself test emails
and look at them on desktop and mobile devices before sending to your prospect list.

Where are the line breaks? Should there be more or less? Do you have a stellar first
sentence above the fold on a mobile device? Everyone skims‚Äîif you write an email that
can be skimmed and easily understood, then you‚Äôll get better results.

Now, when it comes to actually sending cold emails, there are a few questions you want
to answer.

How do I make sure that my emails are getting delivered?
How many emails should I send?
What tool should I use to send them?
Deliverability
Deliverability is the percentage of emails that make it to inboxes (as opposed to spam
folders or firewalls).

High deliverability is necessary for a successful cold outreach strategy. Think: you‚Äôve
done all the hard work of finding the right targets, getting their email addresses, and
crafting emails to them accordingly. It‚Äôs inefficient if many of your emails don‚Äôt even
make it to inboxes.

Here‚Äôs the 80/20 on improving your deliverability. Don‚Äôt skip these steps:

Create a separate subdomain for sending cold emails. For example, if your usual
email is jsmith@company.com, set up a separate subdomain and use
jsmith@e.company.com to actually send emails from. This way, if anything goes
wrong (rare), you haven‚Äôt trashed your main domain.
Avoid spam filters by avoiding keywords commonly used in spam emails. This is
less important than how your recipients engage with your emails, but it‚Äôs still
worth avoiding these words.
Follow all legal advice we mentioned earlier.
Most importantly, get your targeting right. You improve deliverability by getting a
high rate of replies, and low rate of unsubscribes and spam reports. So only send
emails to people you truly think will benefit from your product.
A few additional strategies that will help improve your deliverability over time:

Don‚Äôt batch-send all your appointment reminders and follow ups at once. Stretch
them out over a few hours or over the day.
Avoid including too many images or too much HTML in your emails. One of the
spam flags that you can avoid is the ratio of text to other content.
Limit your links‚Äîespecially to social networking sites. And try to avoid bit.ly and
other link shorteners as they‚Äôll get picked up by spam flags.
You can also use a tool like Mailwarm to get positive engagements on your emails
before you start sending at scale. What you‚Äôre looking for is "regular email traffic" and a

responsible slope to higher volumes that won‚Äôt negatively impact your sender
reputation.

Here are two useful tools to help you keep tabs on deliverability:

Glock: This helps you check how your emails are inboxing (how many inboxes you‚Äôre
reaching). Ideally, cold emails make it to the primary tab and not the promotions tab.

Postmaster Tools: Gmail's feedback loop tool. This helps you understand how Gmail
recipients are interacting with your emails.

Email Cadence
Let‚Äôs revisit our cold email strategy from earlier:

You‚Äôve already created your 2-3 emails. Let‚Äôs assume that you have a list of about 1,000
prospect‚Äôs email addresses to send to.

Here‚Äôs the most effective way to run your first campaign:

Start with an initial test run: an A/B of the 2-3 email archetypes you‚Äôve created
(~100 emails for each archetype is enough).
Analyze data to see which email had the best reply rate and booked meetings
rate. Then send the winning email to the rest of your list.
Continuously iterate on your emails.
First test run: 100-300 emails (~100 per archetype)

You need to send enough emails to reliably know what percentage of your emails get
opened , and what percentage of your prospects take action‚Äî whether it‚Äôs scheduling a
call with you, emailing you back, or just clicking through to your website.

Sure. You could conduct a statistical test if you want to get technical. But considering
the fact that you‚Äôll want to quickly test your archetypes and start sending your winning
email, a good proxy is a test of 100-150 emails total.

We‚Äôve found that‚Äôs often all it takes to find your winning email, measured by response
rate.

Second run: 800-1,000 emails

Send the winning email to the rest of your list. The goal, first and foremost, is to get
prospects to take action on your email. But the secondary goal is to validate the results
you got from your first test run.

What you‚Äôre looking for here is whether or not the metrics from your first test hold true at
scale‚Äîand we‚Äôll cover those metrics, but think: open rate, reply rate, action rate, etc.

Future runs: Find the cadence that works best for your business

Once you have a tight grip on your metrics, you‚Äôll know how many emails you need to
send to get a reasonable flow of leads. Think: You might find out that, instead of sending
emails in bursts, it works better to send out 50-100 emails per day per sales rep which
should result in roughly 10 new leads per day. If you need more / fewer leads per sales
rep each day, you can simply change the cadence.

As you scale, make sure your emails stay personalized, and continuously iterate on the
copy you use to improve your metrics.

We‚Äôll cover metrics shortly, but one important note to keep in mind as you find your ideal
sending cadence: Most businesses would benefit by maximizing ROI, not purely
revenue. High ROI is usually achieved in smaller batches when you can afford taking
the time to personalize.

Follow ups

If someone hasn‚Äôt responded to you after your first email, follow up twice:

‚óè Once after 3 days
‚óè And again after 7 days
After that, it‚Äôs not usually worth continuing. You might find data suggesting that you
follow up 3+ times (some blogs suggest following up over 9 times).

We disagree. After your 3rd unanswered email, you‚Äôre no longer simply being
persistent‚Äîyou‚Äôre being a pest. The damage you‚Äôll do to your brand by spamming
people exceeds the marginal benefit of a few additional sales.

We‚Äôre building self-aware businesses. Stick with 2 follow ups and don‚Äôt spam.

Another reason for limiting your touches: You can recycle these leads sooner. A lead
that doesn't respond to a 3 touch sequence can be emailed again in 5-6 months.

Automate your follow ups through tools like Mixmax, PersistIQ, Mailshake, or Lemlist.
These tools automate multi-email campaigns, and personalize each for the recipient.
They also detect when a prospect replies so they‚Äôre taken out of the sequence and
shielded from receiving more emails.

Make sure your follow ups accomplish the following:

‚óè Add value to your original email. Don‚Äôt waste your prospects‚Äô time with emails
that read, ‚Äúfollowing up on this.‚Äù Instead, make sure each of your follow ups adds
a bit of value.
‚óã ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a video walkthrough of our tool.‚Äù
‚óã ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a case study on how XYZ brand is working with us.‚Äù
‚óè End with a question, not a statement. This tends to open up more
conversations that would otherwise go to closed-lost.
‚óã ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs holding you back from exploring this?‚Äù
‚óã ‚ÄúAre you still facing XYZ problem?‚Äù
You want to build credibility until your prospect can‚Äôt help but respond.

Tools
We recommend using Gmail and something that sits on top of Gmail and sends through
it.

As you scale up, you can level up and afford bigger and more powerful tools.

When you‚Äôre sending thousands of emails, you‚Äôll want to automate most of the process.
Luckily, there are many tools that allow you to automate your emailing: Simply upload a
list, copy and paste your emails (and follow ups) into the tool, add personalization where
necessary, and send.

Here‚Äôs a list of what we‚Äôve used in the past to send emails for clients:

‚óè PersistIQ: Free to start.
‚óã Free plan: 20 emails/day
‚óã Growth plan: 300 emails/day/user
‚óã Enterprise: 600 emails/day/user
‚óè Streak: Free to start.
‚óã Free plan: 50 emails/day/user
‚óã Solo plan: 800 emails/day/user
‚óã Pro plan: 1,500 emails/day/user
‚óè Mixmax: Inexpensive, and it can be directly integrated into Gmail.
‚óã G Suite customers can send up to 2000 emails per day
‚óã But Mixmax caps you at 500/day to prevent senders from getting
rate-limited by Google
‚óè Mailshake: Easy to use, best for people who are just starting out in cold outreach.
‚óã Sending via Gmail, Mailshake limits you to 500 emails/day/user
‚óè Reply IO: Another easy to use tool, and, unlike all others on this list, it has basic
functionalities that can help you to create onboarding or retention drip
campaigns.
‚óã Reply IO caps you at 400 emails/day/user
‚óè Lemlist: Similar to Mailshake with better personalization and email deliverability.
‚óã Lemlist recommends sending no more than 200 emails/day/user
Your sending tools should integrate with a CRM to make tracking easy. We recommend
Pipedrive and Copper for their ease of use and integrations with the tools above.

Measure and Optimize Results
Measuring results boils down to one question: How much does it cost to get a
purchase through cold email?

If your cost of acquiring a customer (CAC) is less than the amount of money you make
from each customer, you‚Äôve validated a channel and you‚Äôre ready to scale up.

Below are additional metrics that will help you increase your cold email performance,
and, thus, decrease your CAC.

Time Spent Per Purchase
Gather a rough estimate of how much time it took you to source, send and respond to
all of your initial emails.

For example, say it takes you:

‚óè 4 hours to source 100 email addresses.
‚óè 3 hours to send and personalize them.
‚óè Another 3 hours to respond before closing.
You spent 10 hours total. If one person purchased out of all of those emails, You‚Äôve
spent 10 hours per purchase.

You can use hours per purchase to figure out whether it‚Äôs worth hiring a salesperson or
a sales team. Be sure to factor in costs for tools (like Hunter.io or Lemlist). While
relatively marginal compared to labor, they should be included in your ROI calculation.

An average account executive in the United States costs about $100,000 per year
including benefits‚Äîthat‚Äôs about $50/hour.

If it takes 10 sales hours per purchase, it costs you $500 per purchase to hire an
Account Executive.

If your product‚Äôs profit exceeds that, it‚Äôs worth hiring.

Note: All percentages below are a percentage of the initial cold emails sent. Numbers
are drawn from our experience sending thousands of cold emails for 50+ startups.
Percentages will vary based on your business type and your audience, but these are
rough benchmarks.

Open rate
The percentage of emails opened.

In cold outreach, open rate is a measure of how enticing your subject line is.

You can improve your open rate by A/B testing your subject line. Before you email your
entire prospect list, send a portion of your list (say, 100 people) two different subject
lines. Then send the rest of your list the subject line that had a higher open rate.

We‚Äôve sent thousands of cold emails for clients, and we‚Äôve found the following metrics
to be true:

Average open rate: 20-30%. Good open rate: 30-50%. Outstanding open rate: 50%+.

Click-through rate
Click-through rate (CTR) is the percentage of emails sent where the recipient clicked an
embedded link.

This is a measure of how enticing your email body is, whether you‚Äôve included a clear
CTA, and whether you‚Äôve emailed the right people.

Note: Keep in mind that using software to track your click-through rate will impact your
deliverability‚Äîinternet service providers (like Gmail) don‚Äôt like tracking software. So
recording anything more than opens can hurt deliverability.

Our suggestion: Start with tracking. Get a handle on your numbers. Then decide if using
tracking is worth the potential decline in deliverability.

Average CTR: 3-5%. Good CTR: 5-10%. Outstanding CTR: 10%+.

Response rate
Response rate is the percentage of your list that responds to your emails.

This is a measure of how enticing your email body and website are combined with how
well you created your targeted prospect list.

In addition, response rate is higher when targets already know who you are (e.g.
pre-targeting covered below). If the goal of your cold outreach is to book meetings, this
is the most important metric‚Äîyou need booked calls to close sales.

Average response rate: 5-10%. Good response rate: 10-20%. Outstanding response
rate: 20%+.

Purchase Rate
Purchase rate is the percent of cold contacts who eventually purchase from you.

For most cold outreach, this metric measures your end goal of acquiring customers.
Even though purchases may take a lot of back-and-forth and take longer than a week,
make sure you‚Äôre tracking this diligently‚Äîthis is how you prove your cold outreach ROI.

If you see high response and click-through rates, but low purchase rates, you‚Äôll want to
improve your sales funnel after the initial email.

Average purchase rate: 0.5%-1%. Good purchase rate: 1-2%. Outstanding purchase
rate: 2%+.

Pre-targeting
Cold outreach performs best when your targets already know who you are.

Two ways to make that happen:

You earn that reputation by building an online following and a strong user base.
Or you pre-target your prospects. Target them with ads before you reach out‚Äîat
least until your brand is a household name.
Pretargeting is running ads to a specific list of email addresses before reaching out to
them.

It boosts open rates and response rates, especially when you‚Äôre targeting people who
need to establish more trust and care about your brand. This tends to be folks in larger,
older companies, or slow-moving industries.

Think about every time you‚Äôve seen an ad. When you see an ad, the product in it feels
more ‚Äúlegitimate.‚Äù While irrational, we subconsciously believe that the company must be
big enough to invest money into an ad campaign.

Facebook and LinkedIn are great because you can upload real lists of emails, and
enough people use the site that a high percentage of them match. So you can serve
ads to the exact individual people you want.

Pre-targeting industries
Here‚Äôs a list of industries that fit well for pre-targeting (larger, older, slower-moving
industries):

‚óè Government
‚óè Construction
‚óè Procurement
‚óè Entertainment
‚óè Hospitals
‚óè Aviation
‚óè Manufacturing
‚óè Supply Chain
‚óè Recruiting
‚óè Real Estate
How to pre-target
You‚Äôll want to test whether pre-targeting actually matters in your industry; otherwise,
your ads will have a low ROI.

‚óè Pull a list of 500 to 1000 emails using the strategies you just learned. This is
Group A.
‚óè Then, pull a list of another list of 500 to 1000 emails using the same strategies.
This is Group B.
‚óè Run ads on LinkedIn and Facebook and directly upload the Group A list (you‚Äôll
want to use ‚ÄúDirect Audiences‚Äù).
‚óè In contrast, email Group B without running ads.
‚óè See which group responds and converts better‚Äîdoes pre-targeting help?
‚óè After your ads hit a frequency of 7-10‚Äîmeaning they‚Äôve been shown to everyone
on your list 7-10 times‚Äîgo ahead and send your cold email campaign.
Since your prospect list is likely full of work emails, you might need to take one
additional step to pre-target effectively. People usually use their personal emails to sign
up for LinkedIn and Facebook, so you‚Äôll likely need personal emails to run direct ads
directly to your prospects. To solve this, you can use Clearbit Advertising to run ads to
the prospects who you will reach out to on LinkedIn. Clearbit Advertising takes your list
of work emails, enriches the data to match work emails to the right LinkedIn and
Facebook accounts, and then generates audiences for you to run your campaigns on.

For a less-expensive alternative, try Primer.

LinkedIn has turned into a viable B2B sales channel. So we decided to write an entire
(public) guide to acquiring customers through LinkedIn.

The main advantage of LinkedIn is its "firmographic" data: business and employee
information you can target by. No other social network has this level of specificity and
consumption context.

LinkedIn is primarily a top-of-funnel channel‚Äîyou won‚Äôt see many deals close directly
on LinkedIn. Instead, LinkedIn should be treated as a tool to find relevant prospects,
engage with them (via content and DMs) and get permission to email them. That‚Äôs when
prospects turn into warm leads.

The LinkedIn strategy looks like this:

Contribute meaningfully to LinkedIn's content pool.
Acquire LinkedIn followers from posting that good content.
Build trust with those followers.
Get their email addresses.
Email them to get off-platform conversion.
If you‚Äôre interested in testing LinkedIn organic as a channel, read the guide here. You‚Äôll
eventually acquire warm leads and repeat the email process we discussed earlier‚Äîwith
additional personalization.

Project: Cold Outreach
This project walks you through a test cold email campaign, from start to finish.

Phase 1: Find emails
Use what you‚Äôve learned from the readings to figure out scalable ways to get email
addresses of potential customers.

Are you going to be using a tool like Clearbit? Scraping websites? Cross-referencing
Crunchbase with LinkedIn? Reference our reading on how to find emails as you go.

This will involve a lot of research. If you can‚Äôt find real, living and breathing emails, you
need to keep searching. At Demand Curve, it usually take us multiple days of research
to come up with viable strategies.

Come up with at least three strategies that result in real emails.

Don‚Äôt stop until you have at least four real email addresses within each strategy you
come up with. That's at least twelve emails total.

This helps us prove that your approach is good enough to do at scale.

Don‚Äôt spend time getting more than the first four emails. Only gather enough to
prove your approach can work. We'll generate giant lists later.

Put the emails you found in a spreadsheet and save them.

Phase 2: Draft your strategy document
Draft a document in Dropbox Paper that answers the following questions:

Who will I be targeting?
Include job titles, company size, and anything else that is relevant when it comes to
finding their email or tailoring the message they get.

Improve your targeting by drilling deeper into their pain points and where they are in the
customer journey (use your value props).

How will I be getting their emails?
Pull this from Phase 1.

What does an initial test look like?
How many emails should you send to start? How will you know if you‚Äôve succeeded?
What‚Äôs the next step after the initial email?

Check out the example strategy document in Cold Outreach ‚Äì Additional Resources >
Outbound Strategy Document based on what Demand Curve has given a real client
(identifying details removed).

Phase 3: Write copy
Draft up a document with the initial cold email copy. Make sure you‚Äôve read our Email
Copy reading first.

Make two versions that have a very different message from each other. Within those,
make a long and a short version.

Go to Cold Outreach ‚Äì Additional Resources > Templates: Cold Email Copy for some
email templates. You can use the same overall layout as the templates, but craft your
own emails. Only reference the copy when you get stuck ‚Äî good copy varies
market-to-market.

Phase 4: Test on yourself
Send an email to yourself in Gmail. Put yourself in the shoes of a prospect receiving the
email. See if it looks spammy.

Look at the snippet you see in the inbox first.

Then open the actual email. At Demand Curve, we‚Äôll actually boomerang the email to
ourselves to be sent in a day, so it looks fresher when we actually read it.

Make sure everything looks compelling. If not, change what needs to be changed.

Phase 5 (optional): Test that you don‚Äôt
go to spam
Use Glock or Litmus to double-check that your emails will pass your recipient‚Äôs spam
filter.

Generally, you won‚Äôt have to worry about this until you‚Äôre sending emails out on a
massive scale (1000+ emails/day).

Make sure to cancel Litmus before your free trial is up or they‚Äôll charge you a boatload.

Phase 6: Gather emails
Make sure you have at least 100 emails of prospects loaded into a spreadsheet. Go
through each prospect, research them, and add a blurb about how you‚Äôll personalize
your email to them in a separate column.

Anything less than 100 emails means you won‚Äôt get reliable data.

Phase 7: Make safety email address
When you send your initial test emails, there‚Äôs a small chance your address will go to
spam or get blacklisted. You‚Äôll want to create a separate subdomain for sending cold
emails so that if anything goes wrong (rare), it won't trash your main domain.

Have this be for the highest-ranking person at the company ‚Äî ideally the CEO if you
have their permission. Emails from them tend to get much better response rates.

For example, if your usual email is jsmith@company.com, make a separate email
address for jsmith@e.company.com to actually send emails from.

This way, if anything goes wrong (rare), you haven‚Äôt trashed your main email. Great.

Next, upload a picture of the person whose email you‚Äôre using, otherwise the account
will look fake when people mouse over their name in gmail. This boosts response rates
30-50%.

Phase 8: Learn mail merge
Now, install Yet Another Mail Merge. We‚Äôre going to test safely that we can send out
multiple emails, without emailing another human being.

Make a Google Sheet like below:

Add only your own email address , and then add one that‚Äôs generated from Mailinator.
Don‚Äôt use real email addresses yet.

Follow steps 2 and 3 here.

Then, go to your email and the Mailinator inbox. Double-check that the emails looks
how they should.

Phase 9: Checklist
Follow this checklist. It‚Äôs what we use internally at Demand Curve.

Phase 10: Go live
Add the real emails of your prospects to the Google Sheet. Plug in the right variables.
Send away.

Use Mail Merge or send manually through Gmail if you need the flexibility to personalize
your emails on the fly. We recommend using Gmail to start and backing into using Mail
Merge if it‚Äôs too time-consuming.

And see those sweet, sweet leads start to come in!

Phase 11: Get data
The more expensive your product, the longer it tends to take to get good data, since
people may take a long time to actually purchase and move through your funnel.

Check back after 4-5 days.

Then, make a spreadsheet with all the important data you need (hint: it‚Äôs in our reading
on Sending Cold Emails). Figure out whether it‚Äôs profitable for you to continue.

Overview
This document covers who we‚Äôll be emailing, how we‚Äôre getting their emails, and what
our initial tests will look like. We can scale up if we see success.

Audiences
People who have indicated interest in premium dog products. Specifically, there are two
main audiences we‚Äôll be starting with:

‚óè High-end dog owners in the Dog Food Lovers Slack group.
‚óè Participants in dog-food related conversations in the Doggie Moms Google
group.
Email Harvesting
Dog Food Lovers

We‚Äôve written a scraper to programmatically go through their Slack channel and pull the
emails for the owners from each profile. Here is an initial list. First tab.

Demand Curve Note: above would be a link to a spreadsheet with the list of emails;
we've removed it from this example doc.

Doggie Moms

We‚Äôve joined the Google group and exported the list of participants from the ‚ÄúMembers‚Äù
section of the admin panel.

Initial Test
Start by sending LinkedIn InMail. You‚Äôre going to send 10 inMails, total, to start.

You‚Äôll have to purchase a Premium subscription to do this. You only get a fixed number
of InMails per month, but it looks like you can purchase more if you run out.

At the same time, try cold-emailing people directly. You‚Äôre going to send 10 emails, total,
to start.

When you send cold emails, you may want to comply with CAN-SPAM rules, which
govern cold emailing in the United States.

Complying with CAN-SPAM tends to hurt conversion, since it makes cold emails
follow a similar format and people will instinctively screen them out. But we leave
that choice up to you.

Consult a lawyer if you want definite legal advice (we can‚Äôt offer it), but they would
recommend following these guidelines at a minimum:

‚óè Don‚Äôt use false or misleading header information
‚óè Don‚Äôt use deceptive subject lines
‚óè Tell recipients where you‚Äôre located with a physical address (this information can
go in your email signature)
‚óè Tell recipients how to opt-out of receiving future email from you.
‚óè This doesn‚Äôt have to be a link. It can be a line in the email asking them to reply to
you directly if they don‚Äôt want any more emails from you.
‚óè Honor opt-out requests promptly.
You can read more here or read the original text if you really want some bedtime
material.

Don‚Äôt reach out to more than 20 Dog Food Lovers to start, since folks are going to
catch on quickly and if they talk to each other, we‚Äôll start to look like spam.

Stagger out the emails, sending only 1 or 2 per day.

We need our outreach to be natural. Since we know that pet owners tell other pet
owners about Fictitious Dog Chow, you can ‚Äúland and expand‚Äù without actually sending
many emails. You‚Äôll ask for owners to refer other owners, in person, at the end of their
trial if it goes well.

We‚Äôll rely on further emails as a crutch, not as a centerpiece of our outreach strategy.

However, it‚Äôs safer to email owners who are broadly dog owners, or in a more publicly
available Slack channel. We‚Äôve scraped a list of these owners: the 1000 most recent
participants in the Doggie Moms Slack channel. They‚Äôre in the second tab of the sheet.

Make sure you haven‚Äôt already reached out to these people when you email them (the
Dog Food Lovers are in the same list).

Aim for people who were active in the last month. We‚Äôre planning to segment this list
further in the future to find past dog food purchasers and pet owners who are closer to

buying gourmet. If you send out too many similar emails from Gmail per day, it will start
marking you as spam and blacklist your domain (usually once you‚Äôre in the hundreds).
So you need to be careful about not sending too many.

Email response rates over 10% are considered good. The best we‚Äôve ever seen is
~50%, with targeting even better than what we have here.

Content
It‚Äôs going to come off as creepy if you say that you know owners are in the Dog Food
Lovers group. You‚Äôll need to write a subject line enticing enough to make them click, but
have a convincing enough excuse for why you‚Äôre reaching out to get them to respond.

You‚Äôll mention Dog Food Lovers as an aside in the email, but not make it the focus.

Stick to the templates we‚Äôve written pretty closely if you can. We‚Äôve spent hours
perfecting these.

For the variables that you‚Äôre plugging in:

‚óè Find any public information indicating that they're a Dog Food Lover.
‚óè This is ideal and the most straightforward.
‚óè For example, there are a few owners who already list that they have a dog in
their Twitter profile. You‚Äôll want to check those.
‚óè Install the Clearbit Connect. Plug in their email. See what shows up.
‚óè Look through their LinkedIn.
‚óè Google them. Reference Tweets/Blog Posts/Social Media that indicated they‚Äôre
interested in premium dog food.
‚óè Reference their city and talk about how gourmet dog food has gotten rave
reviews there.
‚óè Research anything else you can about them to give you a compelling excuse to
reach out.
‚óè In general, you‚Äôll want to do three things to write high-converting emails:
‚óè Make them feel like the email is personalized to them in the context they read it.
By context, we mean Gmail, a mail app, or LinkedIn.
‚óè Immediately entice them with a solution to their problem.
‚óè Close with a clear next step.
You need to hook owners with the subject line and first blurb they read.

Emails read very differently in Dropbox Paper than they do in Gmail or LinkedIn, so
send yourself a sample email in Gmail before sending out to see what the emails will
actually look like.
